Entry.1:
All this morning I wandered about in the glorious wilderness garden making plans of it even the tree & shrubs. 

In the afternoon we go over to Foxholm crossing meadows yellow as mustard with buttercups & through a belt of ancient timber growing on a very steep slope which has cloud like blue mists apparently rolling up its side. This fairy cloud are really millions of little blue bell which in big patches here are without number & were well worth the visit.

Foxholm is an old Tudor built house in the middle of a 
space
 clearing in a plantation. The forest has been cleared a little too much round house & at the present time is neither thick enough to be wild & too thin enough to be beautiful. I see some old birch with their white bark, with little round leaves. The lime seems the best of the deciduous here, for it grows fast & does not rob the ground under it like the beech. The elm grows too slowly.
Entry.2:
All leave today for London except myself & I am going the other way

1

this afternoon. I return the pony & trap to Foxholm before leaving the pony now quite understands me & will come to my call, much to other peoples surprise –

I met Baines at Foxholm & search for trains & finally wander home through the fields of fragrant bluebells to the Manor House, where I dine on in the big dining room & then have a final walk in the wilderness which has quite caught my fancy & set off for Weybridge which has a choice of routes to Codford but the time of connection the official refuses to disclose as it would mean travelling by the other company

This lands me at Salisbury & I revisit the cathedral & glorious exterior & plain interiors to of which admission is charged, eg chancel – always & casus belli to me & finally reach camp about 7 pm
Entry.3:
No new through to-day but visit QM see Cpl Costing & change all my gear & hand in overcoat & trousers as I have no need for them. No one has yet returned from leave – everything including meals is go as you please – 

Visit Education officer & see Mearns who is in charge of matters & promises

to make a special mention of my case at London to night which by the way he neglected to do. Rest of officers return from leave including Simpson with whom I yarn & discuss future plans he being very much in favour of banana growing.
Entry.4:
More officers return including Allen who is very excited about his NME. I dont look for work no one knows I am here so I keep out of sight in my cubicle & read. 

At night I walk through Stockton Park & past the quaint little thatched house that I have described before. These are cleaner than those of French farmer but the cleanliness seems a burden for nowhere are the face so contented as the frenchman seems to be even when in the midst of squalor. This contentment is something I could desire very much, & is surely a great national asset
Entry.5:
Inoculated today & had time I have for Major Clark has into the bone. I send wires to everyone I know to day hoping to get

across much quicker. 

Tonight I walk into & return along the river bed & through meadows on which a large amount of irrigation has been done In parts the stream sinking into a steep hollow look from the high banks (tree clad) just like a burn in Scotland.

Everywhere the hawthorn is in bloom and hedges apart from the slight perfume are simply glorious a wavy line of moving white for in expectation of blooming the hedges have not been cut. Often we come upon red hawthorn which is even pretty than the white when close to it though in the distance the colour does not show up so well as the white
Entry.6:
11.30 This morning I get message to report tomorrow as the wire supposed to have been sent on 14/5/19 has now arrived. 

To night I climb up the hill to have what will probably be my last look at Codford & remark on the fact that while the valley is full of trees & contains the best land it is the hills around that are cultivated. This is because perhaps the valley is the only part possible for meadow land for this

is intensely irrigated.

The monotonous call of the cuckoo here haunts one for it is unceasing & has no music like the lark now trilling so clearly in the sky above.
Entry.7:
Leave camp at 9 but do not catch train till 1 pm & then pay my fare to Salisbury as there is a train for France via Southampton which leaves from this station & so if I go by this route I need not change my baggage 

I leave my baggage in the cloak room & have dinner at Chinese restaurant (4/10) where I met 2 African airmen who volunteer to take me up in their plane if I can get leave to go up to Northolt junction before I leave. I then find Lily Brookes & take her to the pictures after which I go home to Baywater Rd
Entry.8:
Get up this morning at 11.30 & take a walk in the park & listen to the speeches There is a big police meeting here to day to decide if the London police should strike. I ask a policeman what I can do to fill in time & suggests going up the river in the boat & I add visiting Kew Gardens to myself.

The interval I fill in by visiting Cleopatra’s
Entry.9:
needle which is very dilapidated & black when compared with it clear cut & well preserved companion in the Place de la Concorde. The 
lio
 sphinx on upper side is much cut about as result of a bomb dropped in this vicinity & I understood that the damage is not to be repaired but left as a souvenir of the war.

The current of the river is fairly strong & the water very dirty. Opposite is the unfinished County Council building in the excavation for the foundations of which a Roman boat was found, & several other Roman relics. The first part of river trip is not very interesting as it is really London & the busy commercial centre, the name of many factory being well known eg Doulton whose premises stretch for nearly a mile – Cross & Blackwell 

Further up the river becomes more interesting. Locks begin. In places river is banked up by weirs to keep water at nearly same level & the method of travelling is to enter a basin & the gate is shut behind you & then the bassin is filled to level of other side by valves & then the other gate is opened & you continue your

journey. 

The boats here are often square ended punts & the method of propulsion poling – a inane method that only an Englishman would continue for it has no advantage either in ease or speed of propulsion.

One thing that would not be tolerated in Australia is the shameless cuddling that takes place right in the crowded river. Hang it all we do go into the bush. Another is the prevalence of smoking among the women. 

River is very pretty & it simply teems with life the house parties on shore & hotels & tea gardens that fringe the bank. Richmond with its terrace concealed by lofty trees but still showing its Star & Garter hotel is passed & many places once the abode of the aristocracy & still bearing trace of that refined beauty which a cultured & leisured class always leaves in its wake

We pass Hampton Court which I have visited before & go a fair distance past it. I then go to catch a bus for Kew & find a long queue waiting so I put myself in it & walk on first bus & get to Kew. 

These gardens far surpass the Botanic gardens & are now for more beautiful than when I saw them last which was in winter & the trees were leafless. The azalea are wonderful while the valley of the

7

Rhododendrons 
are
 is a thing of beauty, the memory of which passeth now away. A mass of gorgeous blooms of every conceivable colour & every inch often 15 or 20 ft high a mass of blooms 

Thence I pass the walk which leads to Queens Cottage – a concentration of rustic loveliness & wildness – without an apparent sign of human attention save the handrail on path & the notices.

On return everyone has same idea all bus places are lined with people in queues & I take underground Ticket collector tells me to take the first train & change at Hammersmith. I take the first train & after passing about 12 station ask where Hammersmith is & am told that I am in wrong train & return to station whence I started. 

At last after nearly 3 hours travelling during which I have been as far north as Camden Town I reach London such is the railway & generally speaking the Londoners idea of humour. 

Arriving in London at 10.30 I have difficulty in getting meals & even the policeman cannot tell me a place. However, I fossick one out for I rarely take a midday meal as my money is not sufficient to allow such extravagance. Room cost 8/- & meals 6/- or 7/- sometimes

a little less & as this exceeds my pay I must go careful or else I shall be bankrupt.
Entry.10:
I report at Georges Square & am sent on to DAAG at Horseferry Road who wants to send me back to Georges Square but ultimately finds the papers in his own office. 

As I must wait 4 days to report back on Thursday for my orders. I then try to collect the allowance payable last march & I am told that it has been posted to my unit. When I tell them I shall never see the unit again they consent to enter the amount in my pay book. 

I then visit Harrowby & Lady Francis strafes me for not going to Mrs Wilkinson. 

I visit the Daily News – a daily & see all through the printing works from the reproduction of photographs with their dots to the machine which prints & rolls & turns out 20,000 copies in 19 minutes – This is a double machine. 

From the linotype I get my name set up. I see the linotype block made from paper & the molten metal does not burn it though it is only paper covered with a solution. It is cast in cylinder form & put in machine

9

I have afternoon tea with the Wilkinsons Portland Square & then at night visit Palace Hotel where an informal dinner is being held & a Masonic Club is being inaugerated. 

An invitation is given to Motherland Lodge where the Prince of Wales has recently been initiated. I met an American Mayor & had a long discussion about Universities which are very similar lines to our. Also met Fred Bland & Watts from Lands Title Office. Went to Room of Earle Wayne Whitney Capt & Attorney at law Wewoka Oklahoma & then wandered home

3-6-19

This is the day for my aeroplane stunt so I catch 10.29 train from Paddington for Northolt Junction a sleepy little place with about 2 houses but none near station It is on a branch line & they run a single railway carriage to it. 

I meet Henstridge who cannot get a machine & as an alternative shows me all the different types of planes Snipe – Bristol – Kitten etc. & then as Mayor has gone he gets an Avro out & up we go I am not least frightened of accident to machine for his life is equally as dear to him as mine is to me & he is not going

to take any risks now war is over. 

When
 My only fear is my heart but when he side stalls & I feel no evil result he does what he like – the whole program – the loop is unnoticeable except that it is funny to see the earth on your head & the sky under your feet the shimmy nose dive & the 
leaf fall
 falling leaf shake your stomach up & leave it round your ears

I then have dinner at the aerodrome & return to London now the worse for the adventure. I now want to get into a submarine & then I shall have completed in water – under water & in air.
Entry.11:
Visit Harrowby although this is Derby Day but I do not know the horses & do not see the use of wasting all days in queues & being crushed especially as I have little money to spare. 

I visit Mrs Talbot of 32 St George Road Eccleston Square with Mrs Gore for luncheon. She is one of the Buxtons & a Miss Buxton is present the exact replica of Mrs Rutson.

The old joke of numbering street entirely upsets Mrs Gore & if an English person cannot understand the system how can a

11

stranger solve such conundrums.

I visit Alcocks in the afternoon & then dine with Miss Rose Richards 38 Hyde Park Gates near Albert Hall. Here the party consists of 2 other Lieutes from USA though in RAF & Ralston from Sydney. We play poker & at last hand I wage all & end up by losing 5/-. 

This is night of Savage Ball at Albert Hall & there are rows of taxi & a good crowd of people even at this time (midnight) to watch the costumes. I try to cross Hyde Park but this is closed at 12. Fancy closing our domain at 12 for Hyde Park has nothing valuable in it like the Gardens. These people are not as civilised as Sydney. The Tubes also stop at 12 & there are none which run an all night service.
Entry.12:
Orders to move have arrived & I start to morrow – 6.45 am. I rush about pricing clothes but afraid to buy lest I should be stranded in Paris, though I know clothes will cost almost double in Paris. 

My pay book is taken from me & an account will be opened in Paris at Lloyd Bank. I am again at Chinese restaurant & after that get my luggage from Paddington to Victoria whence the train starts. 

I meet Evans on my 
back
 road home & yarn for an hour

or so & then return to my domicile intending to get up at 5 am but with some thoughts of missing the train & catching the next
Entry.13:
I rise at 5 am but do not start for 6.45 am which naturally I miss. Arriving in time for 8.30 am I am informed that I cannot travel by it so wait till 10.30 which does not go as far as wharf & costs me the expense of transportation to wharf though assured by officialdom that I need not worry. 

At Folkestone I met 2 Yankee medical officers with whom I dine & visit the township of Folkestone. 

Embark on Princess Victoria at 2.45 & a sailor picks up a chair from a heap & puts it down 2 ft away & expects a tip for this – usually 6d or 1/-. This is the way you are robbed in England by English people One can forgive the continental people to some extent because we are foreigners & so liable to be exploited 

Arrive at Boulogne & boat enters from sea stern first as there is no room to turn in harbour without inconveniencing the traffic & perhaps the knife edged design is difficult to handle if she has not much way. 

I go to Club & then go for a

13

walk down to Jitee & along the sea front. The child like prank that grown ups can play reflect this light tempered race, eg a man tries to overturn a little shelter where his mother-in-law & wife is sitting. Another man rolls his wife over in the sand & both find it funny I should find it uncomfortable but they dont seem to mind.

Men & women take advantage of the evening to go for a stroll but no one dresses. They go as they are when the idea comes into their head. And the girls seem proud of their lovers even though he be in working drabs & they seem to get a lot of pleasure out of their evening stroll.

I saw one boat come alongside quay & it showed that Frenchmen were never made to handle boats. 2 well dressed girls & their mother at top of wharf are amused & the sailors exchange remarks with them as if they were old friends. There is no resentment & no forwardness. It all seems natural here. 

At the club all are English & I am isolated. I now never speak to an Englishmen unless he first speaks & then I sometimes only answer rarely. My dislike for the average Englishman is daily increasing
Entry.14:
After a good sleep & bath & breakfast at 10 (porridge egg & bacon 2 ½ fr. bath 1 fr. dinner 4 f) I set off to see the town. 

The town is divided into Hauteville. The old wall town of history & the Basse Ville – the town which has since developed. The port across the river being known as . The fisher folk still retaining their peculiar & distinctive areas espec on Sunday lie in a quarter to themselves. 

The streets nearby railway are disgusting filthy & if they had much hot weather & less rainfall the whole population would be swept off by disease. Still I should say that this is due to the crudeness of their ideas of sanitation rather than filthiness for in some things they are scrupulously clean & the absence of inspectors of nuisance in our own towns would let a number of dirty conditions spring up 

The old town is the more interesting The old ramports still remain as a pleasant walk covered in shade by rows of trees planted upon it, & scattered throughout its length are seats to rest the weary limb & often used by lover where Mdlle has managed to slip away from work for a little while to discuss some matter of vital interest only to themselves. 

The walls are & 60 ft 

15

high & the trees in the surrounding avenues below mars the view, as these trees are ancient & lofty. At one point on north west corner the trees open & a glorious view is obtained of surrounding hills here & their covered with isolated clumps of trees. 

In winter these trees would be leafless & the panorama would balance the loss of the shady retreats. The day is very hot but underneath these trees lofty & cool the shaded walk are filled with a cooling breeze & the air itself is full of the song of myriad of birds who have found these pleasant parts.

The Church of Notre Dame is in the Italian style The roof is doubled the lower one having huge semicircles & the upper painted group above these semicircles gives the idea of a glimpse into Heaven. The decoration is all in a silver grey. The dome is closed till 2 pm but I do not wait. The Palais de Justice, Hotel de Ville are beautiful building whose beauty is robbed by the narrow streets which are so hot & sultry that I again seek the ramparts. 

I then set off to visit the Colonne de la Grande Armee & ask a Frenchman who instead of merely directing me he accompanies me & makes interesting conversation to pass the time unlike an Englishman

who if polite enough would merely give you wrong direction & walk on alone.

The Avenue to Colonne consists of a road flanked with trees then a narrow walk & on outside about 6 ft dense shrubs & trees & a hedge. Around the Colonne 
are
 is a dense park & numbers of strips of grass belts. . In squares around base are areas containing 700 each little rounded plants. 

The Colonne is 172 ft high of white marble Napoleon on top dressed as a Roman with his back turned on England – meant as an insult but perhaps prophetic as showing that the path of glory did not lie in that direction. The description of the country from the top is best seen from the pc. I cannot see England as there is a heavy fog to sea portions of which roll inland occassionally like an invading army. 

At night I wander along to ruins of Caligula ruined lighthouse which he built in 4010 to light the Channel for his ships & there with the town & Establissement des Bain at my feet. Overhearing a remark of two French chaps below they join me & we wander into the town & catch the train. 

As first is too crowded I take the second & get 

17

a very good seat compartment all to myself & stretch out. A sleeper would have cost me 25 fr. & this is as good, I spend all the night travelling
Entry.15:
Arrived in Paris Gare du Nord & set out for Hotel Windsor & have a bath & breakfast – meet Miss Andrews from Leura & Miss Wilson who is in charge 

I take room & go for a walk down city to fill in time as I have made arrangements to go with this party 
to
 on the river up as far as the Maine to down as far as St Cloud. The river is not pretty being spurned by numerous bridges & lined on the bank by historic buildings. However near St Cloud its forest clad hill in which scarcely a house can be see is beautiful.

We land at St Cloud & take refreshment, & then return to Hotel where after dinner I help Miss Wilson to make Orangeade.
Entry.16:
I get up too late to have breakfast – & all the ringing in the world seems unable to rouse the girl so I miss my bath. I report in accordance with my orders & find no one there as this is Whitsunday

a universal holiday & all British officers are not supposed to work on holidays in the army not even in reliefs – I go back to hotel & for the afternoon go to St Cloud races.

At first the betting system worries me how the prices 5 fr 10 fr 50 fr at each bets are made in these prices You can bet that horse wins or that it gets a place & the prices are determined afterwards. You are ignorant at the time. Horses names are not used only the numbers. Horses running & results of last race & prices paid are shown on an indicator. I do fairly well ending up losing about 16/- not as bad considering I knew absolutely nothing of the horses & no one on the ground. 

Leaving course with friend I had found I went to Rue des Paradis & thence to Restaurant Rabbie 69 Boiel Magenta en face de la Gare de L’Est where I met M & Mde Cayer & Oliver a retired French captain & Lucille. They give me a pleasant evening. The freedom from restraint & other peoples opinion on their own innocent enjoyment is very refreshing after the staidness of England.

After dinner we take café in those open spaces in the street so dear to Parisian life. Here the enjoyment is fast & furious. A lady singer looking for arrives & her

19

song is silenced by the audience who takes it up 
all
 In street people stop but everyone takes it as natural & joins in. 

At dinner M. Cayer a regular customer has a complicated bill so girl allows him to make it out himself just fancy such trust in Australia. When you order entrees you are served with a little saucer with the price marked on it. No one asks you to pay & you may remain 1 or 2 hours. If you pay the saucer is turned upside down and no one thinks of turning saucer upside down without paying or of putting saucer in your pocket. Such trust is startling to me. 

On my way back I am lost & have to make many enquiries to go home but everyone is eager to help & some go out of their way to show me.
Entry.17:
I report & find that no one knows of me or cares for me I am a loose end & can apparently do as I like. I find my way to the University seeking a M. as no one knows Dr Siegfried & find myself in with the Americains. The Sorbonne has closed but an Americain course is continuing for 2 weeks and I join with it finding these Americans who

are mostly legal men a fine lot of fellows. 

Money is running very low & I am going without one meal a day & taking no amusements till I know where I stand. I wish I had some account on which I could draw. I have £15 on me due to my account at London but I am frightened to spend a penny till I know when my next pay will be forwarded. How I shall last till November I have not the slightest idea but I mean to stay here all the same even if I have no meals & no bed. 

All the organisations & clubs are closing & there is no recourse. Even the Americans are closing down in July I am continuing the American course until its conclusion & then I shall have to take a tutor whose fees will be 10 fr per hour. The University people give me a lot of address at which I can find board & lodging ranging from 80 fr to 300 fr.
Entry.18:
I spend all the morning looking for rooms & visiting the addresses which have been given to me. Most of the rooms will not be free until the student vacant in some cases 15 day in other a month & finally take rooms temporarily in Hotel des Grand Hommes in Place de la Pantheon at 70 fr

21

per night. I then set out to collect my baggage as I am frightened it may have gone astray but find enormous crowds around the entrance. Here as at tram stop if there is a crowd you can always take a ticket thus ensuring your turn in proper order. This is especially useful in the case of trams while this strike continues. 

At railway I have difficulty in getting a taxi & a YMCA Aussi comes along & offers me his big motor lorry which takes me first to Windsor & then to hotel & for which I give then 10 f. It would probably have cost me 25 f in a taxi & ie if he would have taken me, for during strikes short runs mean more money. 

I dine at Rabbie tonight & meet my friends but leave them to look after my baggage.
Entry.19:
I visit Grand Magasins du Louvre & Samantaine looking for this book & walk along the Grand Boulevard when even in daylight the queens of love & powder are plying their trade. I take in a modest place & get little for 7.50 & in the afternoon I attend my first lecture, & seem to be the only one who can follow his little jokes

To night I find a little café where one can dine conveniently well for 3 to 4 francs & which several American officers have turned into a mess. I meet here a fine chap & destined to be my sole companion.
Entry.20:
This day I have nothing to eat till dinner & have a long yarn with Madam who runs the hotel. Louvre again this evening at 3.30 till 6.0 pm & then invites me to the concert organised by the Americans prior to their departure. 

I spend all the morning in the garden de Luxemburg the prettiest gardens in this pretty city. The play of fountain & walls of spray from the watering pipes under shaded walk among sculptures lends an enchantment to this fairy dell of green grass & greener trees. 

Alongside of me is a musical student who is huming Il Balen & on the other side a would be artist who is spending his time feeding the sparrows with morsels of bread which he has specially brought hither for the purpose
Entry.21: Rose in time to go to concert which is really excellent A W Browning an American
Entry.22:
officer possessing a remarkable voice while S Dushken is a fine violinist. Among the French Mdlle Mona Gondra sang some old French songs which were more action than song but she is . She gave as an encore oh johnny & made love to pianist & finally pulled him out of the chair which certainly terminated the song. Among the American student songs I was rather surprised to find “Once in the dear dear days beyond recall". 

To night I dined at the little café & meeting Maintor visit Montmartre. The Café du Ciel is open but Enfer is closed. Entrance is 2f 50 & on entering one sees fat old objects dressed as monks who ring wooden bells & worship the golden calf. The room is small with a long table down the centre & alcoves in the side. You can take & are expected if at table to order a glass of inferior beer (75 centimes). Then there is a tableaux of supposed angels in tights on pouring out champagne to the other – not bad looking wenches – these are apparently the heavenly residents though they would be just as happy anywhere else I should say.

After a few more we are invited to ascend to upper room which is decked out like the interior of a house & in distance another

stage with clouds shown or reflected on a mirror. 

Here angel Gabriel appears at monks call or rather does not appear & he has to go behind the scenes to find her. At second call she appears & is more like a actress or tight rope dancer than angel. She revolves upside down & in all positions & then anyone in the audience is asked to represent Gabriel. One girl volunteer & as she passes in the monk declares that there goes an angel almost Everyone laughs & badinage is rampant. This girl is given a pair of wings & revolves around. Then two other tight clad angels balance on the moon. 

Then applicants for job of angel or monk are called for & a soldier offers. The monk says he will not be able to work tomorrow & his girl answers it does not matter as he is on strike (tho he is a soldier) & so an angel appear alongside of him emptying gold into a basin at his elbow & of being a reflection he is ignorant & disregards. The monk him for the loss of good opportunity to enrich himself. Then a group of beautiful angels appear & then in same way he ignores from outside appear a large pair of to finish the performance. All laugh & soldier return to his sweetheart

25

The heavenly chorus of girls gives a noisy display with tambourines & the audience is informed that search is finished, & they must return to earth receiving a blessing at foot of stairs I forgot to mention that St Peter with his crook welcomed us at door on entering & conducted us into heaven. 

After this we adjourned to Le Chat Noir a much more interesting show. Price of admission is 1.85 & beer costs 75 centimes & was flat. On entering we were greeting with a remark Here are live real Parisians All girls are addressed as Princess, soldier as generals & civilians as monseigneur & some remark passed about each. A lady accompanied by 2 men enter, & are introduced as the man his wife & the baby. A front man entering introduces himself as the l’amant. 

The songs are rather good & at conclusion singers try to sell them. There seem to be 4 male & 1 finale singer & a pianist. How it pays I dont know. The method of acclamation is directed by one of show & many be a succession of 3, 4 or 5 claps repeated 3, 4 or 5 times. The shallow shows are over the odds of the soldier who sees a girl & much movement after which a duel & then his funeral. 

Some of the songs are very hot & much talk is of Americans

of whom several are present but none understand the jokes against them 

The hall is partly underground – with a vaulted roof in imitation masonry & at far end a little stage on left a box for director of performance overhead a window whence drinks are drawn & on the other side a staircase used for performers. .

The walls are adorned with black cats in all position & by drawings by renowned artists probably the proprietors. A representation of jazz band by all nationalities is excellently arranged & the badinage is fare I really amused myself very much & so did my American friend though he could not follow many items. 

On our return we are stopped many times but are to the alluring beauty that frequents Paris by night & near home meet 2 student & then I accompany them to “Rue Mezet & have a drink & then making arrangements to meet them at La Source go home having experienced an strike stricken person on my way home.
Entry.23:
Now 2.30 pm & I have not dressed. Yesterday & today & the preceding day I have spent writing up my diary but most of the impression have been lost on account of the lapse of time. I will

27

try to record any new ones though often it may mean repetition. 

This afternoon I decide to visit Parc de Montsouris & commence to walk there. Day is hot & I have had no meals I dont go very far when I decide to visit parc any day & go up to top of Eiffel Tower 904 ft high an iron structure from where a most glorious panorama of the city can be obtained. 

The people are no bigger than small points & the houses have the same effect as from an aeroplane. Day is clear & every suburb is plainly visible. Clamart with its dense wood & Sacre Cour rising like a whitened – a heathen symbol rising out of a godless city – The direction & names of suburbs are marked above the glass 3rd platform is half glassed in but the
Entry.24:
a few feet higher is exposed. 

Telegram & PC
 can be despatched here but time does not allow me to send one. Paper thrown from top often wander a mile or so before dropping to earth or becoming lost to sight & it is interesting to watch the childish play of expression whether of anxiety or delight that even adults take in this sport. Sunday ascents can be made for 2 fr weekdays 5 fr. Hence place is crowded on Sunday & long queues wait at each platform for cages At one

place I waited for ¾ hours. 

Restaurant is on first floor & attendance likewise prices A glass of water with a couple of slices of orange costs 2 fr, & it takes nearly an hour to get that much French men do not make good waiter. They get needlesly excited & run all over the place forget your order or give it to some one who does not want it. 

I walked back arriving at 8.30 pm so far having had nothing to eat & feeling a little faint as I have walked nearly 12 miles on a hot day. I have a good meal at the little restaurant I have discovered & where one can dine for about 3 fr & dine well with wine, salads & cheese, & strawberries. 

Here I get talking with an American officer & he offers to take me round to some of the less known cafés The first we visit is off Place St Michel on left hand side facing cite. We pass through an archway & some & I begin to think I am in Spain Group of gypsy looking women & wild looking men with guitars seem in abound though they are only about 4 group some presented in groups on the table & some on the grounds – chairs dont exist. 

We pass along an arcade like room ie there is no front into a small room adorned with crude painting with small tables & benches round wall. This leads into another small room reserved only for

arrangements with my American friend to visit the Bohemian life in Montmartre & as he will be leaving in a fortnight I decide to see what he can show me. 

We leave at 5 pm sharp & wander along to Rue Sauluier where we visit Bar des Artistes. This is the rendezvous of the English actresses in Paris. As we sit down there are two asleep on couches with their money bags lying on table yet no one touches them This would be a wonderful place for pick pockets & light fingered gentlemen.

However we passed on from here to another similar institution in Rue Geoffroy Marie where I met Hilda Little & Hetty Hedges of a club mainly Australians known as the B – d Club Then we went to Boulevard des Italians near Wax works & obtained a good meal for 2 fr 75 Rather wonderful in a place where prices range for same meal 20 fr & upwards 

After this we took the Metro (I forgot to mention the strike of trains has ended to day & the service though not good is not bad) The trains go very much slower than similar ones in London. We get off at Lamark & turning to our right ascend the Rue des Saules though no willows are present & the neighbourhood is wild for a city. 

At top we reach “Le lapin agile" a little café & on entering thro a small room find ourselves in a large room lightened by two gas lamps which are shrouded in a red cloth. The light thus 

31

supplied leaving room quite dark till ones eyes are accustomed to it & then in one corner there is a large statute of a Madonna or some angel & on another a crucified figure horribly carved or chopped out with one knee bent & once plastered in silver & now in dust. The tables are bare & round wall runs a bench no other seating accommodation but if crowd is great boxes are handed out 

The proprietor is a little stunted figure with corduroys 16 sizes too big & straggling white beard while the head is always covered with a pointed felt hat which hides a rather intellectual forehead. One could easily imagine him as a rag-picker ready to murder any one for a . I should have certainly put him down at that had I met him outside. He is as wild as his looks & hops about floor yelling & shouting to himself. 

When all are served with drinks he gets his guitar & sings an old love song “Aupres de ma blonde il fait beau (4 times) Aupres de ma blonde il fait beau ." At conclusion he calls upon the poet Goyard to recite some of his masterpiece ie poems composed by himself, the best being La Visiteuse but the recitation part is bad though the poems possess some merit. Then a girl sings. 

Most of the audience is of the student class living a Bohemian existence delighting in art for arts sake

generally proclaiming the fact by some peculiarity of dress, eg big black cravats, long hair, etc. The programme is pleasant & impromptu more like a family musical evening than a café. 

Thence we adjourned to a Bohemian Club “Nostre Logis" 10 Rue Couston where admission is restricted. Here we had the Bohemian world of Murger – big hats, craving look, large cravats all proclaimed that status. On old bird is the reputed spendthrift of the old nobility. Guitar is very much used here & song of 
the
 love are the common type. 

Goyard recites “J’aime tes cheveux blonds" We talk & yarn & drink (one drink only a glass of water with 3 slices of lemon & sugar 3 fr) & leave about 2.30 am. for a four mile walk home. Still evening has been a pleasant glimpse into Bohemia & I shall often revisit it. 

In fact one of the party is a girl with a lovely voice who sing me songs of Chaminade & Verlaine. I agree to continue our acquaintance to morrow. This girl we accompany home & in spite of her education & high poetic soul find she is reduced to ironing by night & washing by day Until 2 years ago she was a dancer but when stagework fell off her old Bohemian instincts reasserted

33

themselves & she returned to the life which still held its charm amidst a thankless world
Entry.25:
Met the in Café Legrand Place Blanche which still holds the Moulin Rouge & decide to spend the evening visiting the same places as the previous night.

Notre Logis is more interesting & more talent to present plays nocturne after nocturne from Chopin. I met a young painter named Caillous & accompany him home leaving the girl among her friends who will see her home
Entry.26:
There is a dinner tonight at Military Cercle Rue di Volney the aristocratic French military Club of Paris to receive 2 Americains. I have asked permission to be present & so make a friend of Duke an American on GHQ once stationed in Paris who goes out of his way to make friends for me. 

Dinner costs 13 fr & we get champagne & an excellent concert The Club rooms were the War Office of 1849 & are spacious. All servitors wear white stockings. The court is a green lawn & cool & inviting. There are 2 courts.

35

When this will be exhausted I know not where I can find money nor what I can do. 

After changing money in London & County Bank in Place Vendome I went along to Hotel Windsor & find that they are not closing up till end of month & have good yarn with Miss Kellerman & then hurry back to meet an American officer who is taking me round to meet a possible tutor in law for me M Hensson 9 Place Delambre where I spend a pleasant afternoon & am asked if I should like to join the students club. They ask me round on Monday for this purpose but as there is something to pay I am too busy.

Still I am glad to have gained an entrée into this real French family as such introductions are difficult to obtain

Changed residence to Hotel Marigny 13 Rue de Sommerard.
Entry.27:
Spent the morning in the Garden & at 12-30 had an invite to luncheon with Capt. Rouquerol at Press Club 80 Champs d’Elysees (or Champs d’Lizzie)

The building is the magnificent private residence of M Dufayet the man who exploited the cash payment system in Paris. He erected this building at a cost of 50,000,000 fr. & then died. He has no wife nor children nor mistresses so why he built

such a magnificent home I do not know 

The rather vulgar taste of its owner is evidenced by the lavish display of gold everywhere. Naked figures appear everywhere. All the chambers are vast – the private dining room for himself only is twice as large as our ground floor & can seat about 50 people. The great concert room has a stage which rises out of the floor at will & if room is required for a dance subsides again. Near roof there is a hidden galleries on roof of which are several painting of nymphs surrounded by trains & clouds.

Luncheon preceded by cocktails & followed by cigars is very pleasant. My companion is very interesting & as 
my
 his ideas coincide with I promise to buy him an edition. I leave him about 4 pm & visit Villejuif to find Angels friend but find the mother & 2 children with scarlet fever & the girl is away at Montmartre all day & only returns about 7 pm to her home.

To night on the Boulevarde I met a Lt Donnet an English officer in the Royal West Kent whom I had previously met at Cox Bank. He invites me to his rooms at Wagram for a drink. His suite is magnificent an enormously large room filled with roses & on

37

corner of building with large bedroom & a washroom opening off it 

Suite cost 90 fr per day (20/- = 29.80 fr). The view is superb but yet melancholy. The dark & gloomy Tuileries hiding as it were some secret deed of shame or nothing a vague unknown & beyond in the midst of garish light rises the obelisk or is it the guillontine on the Place de la Revolution

On the left stretches that stupendous pile of buildings known as the Louvre while at every instant that part of the Tuileries in front change with the changing light. One can almost see the shade of the courtly seigneurs & stately dames who once walked these squares which were formed & made to suit another age
Entry.28:
long as the Tuileries remain so long will Louis XIV & his age dominate Paris & remain alive in French & foreign minds 

Leaving Wagram (where Paderewski is staying) after considering a proposition put up by Donnet that I should assist him for a week offering £10 as wages or a share in a business of colossal proportions Somehow or other I dont trust the man & I think he is dealing with the enemy & so do not close but in spite of my lack of funds think that I better leave him alone & remain without money.

I spend night at

Hotel De L’Yvonne near the rue a where Mathilde the friend of an American officer lives.
Entry.29:
This is the day that I have received the invite to M. Edouard Dolleans Rue Marbeau. He is a professor of the Law School & has some political pull He is the centre of a very nice social circle & I enjoy myself very much. Remaining dancing till nearly 8 pm I meet a M. Truechi a Professor of Law school & he thinks it is hopeless for me to get a law degree or official recognition but will make enquiries from the Dean. 

I dine with Duke at his rooms tonight & we yarn so late into the night re poetry that I stay the night at his place in Rue de Petite Ecuries
Entry.30:
Spend day with Loepp – dine at YMCA & then to Mont . We return to Rue de Montaigne to meet Duke & then decide to go to a concert. While at dinner siren sounds & we know that Germans have signified their intention of signing the peace We decide to visit the town & if

39

there is any excitement to remain in town. Guns are fired near Champ de Mars but so far few people are 

“L’Enfer"

Cabaret Artistique

(Paris-Montmartre)

Entrée : 2 Fr. 50

(Tous droits compris)

Consommations En Sus

A conserver et a presenter a toute Requisition

No 1231

has been torn up & every vehicle stopping owing to difficulty is attacked by crowd. Further along dancing is common. Altogether considering the French temperament it is a mild display but perhaps the long time since cessation of hostilities has somewhat damped enthousiasm or perhaps I shall see more on the night when peace is signed ie Tuesday, Thursday & later on it is fixed for Friday. I leave Duke

“L’Enfer"

Cabaret Artistique

(Paris-Montmartre)

Entrée : 2 Fr. 50

(Tous droits compris)

Consommations En Sus

A conserver et a presenter a toute Requisition

No 1231

39

there is any excitement to remain in town. Guns are fired near Champ de Mars but so far few people are stirring so we attend concert in Theatre in Champs Elysee a beautifully furnished place with a roof of hidden light which illuminated the frescoes & the building but which was itself invisible. 

After performance we visited Boulevards. Crowds have now arrived but beyond trying to or forming a chain across the street & enveloping people & then romping round them in a circle there is little excitement. We enter café Grand & beyond a little larger & noisier crowd it is the same. 

We descend to Taverne Olympia & there matters are livelier. Everyone dances with anyone & place is a revel of victory nest & return to Boulevards. Processions are formed & in one place road has been torn up & every vehicle stopping owing to difficulty is attacked by crowds. Further along dancing is common.

Altogether considering the French temperament it is a mild display but perhaps the long time since cessation of hostilities has somewhat damped enthousiasm or perhaps I shall see more on the night when peace is signed ie Tuesday, Thursday & later on it is fixed for Friday. 

I leave Duke

spend the night at Hotel du Centre near Porte di St Denis near which a little girl has been singing for my especial benefit. “Pres de la porte de St Denis till I imagine that I am among my beloved isles again with Mdlle Bozon.
Entry.31:
After turning in about 6 am this morning I remain in bed till 3 pm & then visit Bank to see if my money is across & find that I am still without pay & may be stranded any day. 

I then dine at our little restaurant & then go a dance organised for American officers by the French Homes. After being without a partner I am introduced a lady with a & Mdlle Madelon Le Neef Rue de la Sorborne. She is a dental student & after a dance or two we adjourn to the garden in the house which was once the home of Napoleon physician & then the residence of M. Ribot. 

We talk over philosophic matters & become firm friends I accompany her home & then we decide to visit the town & see if there is any excitement We have a very pleasant promenade & then walk home

The town is still crowded

41

but on the whole very quite
Entry.32:
I rise at 10 am & breakfast in bed & then write up diary from 18/6/19. 

In the afternoon I meet Duke at 53 Ave Montaigne which is the American HQ or rather one of them for they are over organised which perhaps accounts for their failure as an army unit. We drive down in a car to Place du Theatre Francias & dine at for 4.50 fr which is cheap considering locality. 

After this as it is too early to visit Montmarte & Duke wishes to meet someone at 8 pm who incidentally does not turn up. We take coffee at Grand Café & met one of Duke friends & we arrange a little dinner for tomorrow night. 

About 9 I take the lead to introduce Duke into Bohemia for he has been very good to me. We visit Café Enfer This adjoins & is similar to Ciel. Demons await on you everywhere – Consommations cost 75c – Red lights & red decorations 

Place resembles a grotto & the statutes are usually human & guillotined heads with the blood still oozing. Guitar & string band supply music & when hall is full we are invited upstair to the which on arrival is absent. There is a stage & on this a woman is standing in tights & then flames mount at the bidding of Satan & consume her till nothing

remains.

A lady from audience is invited up & one man gives away his sweetheart & tell audience it is a good way of getting rid of her. She appears fully dressed & immediately afterwards is 
in
 almost naked with only a chemise & the Shes in a reflection with her real face. Flames consume & then as they die down she gradually reappears dressed as she was when she mounted platform a minute ago The seven sins are then shown in a series of tableaux After which we are told show is finished & as we pass out door the demon informs us that we are very fortunate to see the earth again. 

As time is getting on I decide to head for L’Agile Lapin & on way meet Goyard. Things are quiet at this place & at 11 pm I take him round to the Society of 10 Rue Couston see The place seems to be losing its Bohemian characteristic owing to an influx of an undesirable element & also of tourists for we found two cars drawn up outside. But these may have been old Bohemians now grown wealthy & visiting old resorts.

Here Duke is fascinated by my little friend Dedi Perry of 38 Rue Fontaine & dances with her. Dancing takes place to night for the first time. We at least, Dedi, Caillous, & I tire & we leave but somehow we find ourselves in Duke

43

flat for coffee – which is followed by chocolat & then & I read & we talk right on till Caillous & Duke decide not to go to bed, so we talk on & a very interesting night we spend. We are 4 3 men & a woman – all without money all Bohemian – a girl – a poet, a painter & myself who might be called a writer

The top attic the freedom of idea & get a girl confident of her self – & when she points to the dawn with a gesture, I hear in every cubic inch of air the strains of Boheme Puccini might have been present in the room. How these words will always conjure up that Bohemian night At length Dedi heart under the strong coffee gives out & we lay her down. 

Is it or not this frail girl whose life has been so full of sorrow that once she tried to end it. We close the door & leave her to her privacy – an act natural to us but so unlike a Frenchman that 
she
 it touches her deeply. About 7 we leave & I go with Caillous to her home
Entry.33:
Caillous atelir in 3 Rue de Campagne Premiere in a courtyard which from above is a green mass 

of waving acacia & from below a summer arbour with flagged floor His studio is a large room adorned with sketches of naked women by himself with a little screen portion for toilette & store & a very large divan or bed. We breakfast on bread & butter & salt & chocolat & then I return home & sleep to 2 pm. 

I look up Capt Rouquerol & find he cannot dine with me, this is fortunate as my fortune consists of 70 fr. & this must last till goodness knows when. 

Then I run across for Duke & find that he has not been in his office & is sick I profess my intention of seeing him at once & the Colonel gives me a U.S car & away I speed to find him.

He was simply exhausted & we set out to buy for tonight’s dinner 6 small veal cutlets cost 7 fr 50 – Sardines are 2.25 f a small tin a small cauliflower costs 3 fr. Unfortunately our guests do not arrive but send a little note We eat the dinner ourselves & then I visit Mde Brisson & have some difficulty in finding the place but it is only within ¼ hr walk from my home.
Entry.35:
Slept till 2 pm & spent afternoon writing up diary This is the day

45

on which peace is to be signed & I go to Versaille to take part in this wondrous event. I go via Montparnasse & so miss much of the crowd though there are over 50,000 there but these are a mere handful in the vast grounds of the Palace. 

To describe Versaille is impossible & God knows what kind of intellect it was which fashioned it. It is stupendous & cost about £20,000,000 & has accomodation for 10,000 inmates The approach has 16 colossal statutes perhaps 20 ft high of statesmen & soldier of Louis XV & in the centre is a statue of the Grand Monarch himself. Each of the pavilions are inscribed with “To the great glories of France" but this is probably by Louis XV 

The Broad Avenue de Paris is lined with thousand of blue clad, steel helmeted cavalry who are guarding every road. The Palace itself is out of bounds save with a ticket which I do not possess 

The grounds are one complicated mass of tree covered avenues & thickets & shrubberies – with temple & fountains & sculptures every at unexpected places Over 100 sculptors were employed embellishing the grounds 

At 10 to 4 the battery of artillery commences. This is signal that peace has been signed & then plenipotentiaries file out & into the terrace & simultaneously the fountains commence to play – & a majestic sight they are though big ones are not in action

This is the first time they have played since the commencement of the war. Then I press forward &am see the plenipotentiaries off & get into the different courts by assuming I have the right to go there & the soldiers let me go & finally return to town. 

At night the town goes mad The Boulevards big as they are are impassable save at a snails paces. The crowd form processions & barge through one procession consists of a Union Jack & 2 Australian flags probably the most conspicuous procession in Paris Place de l’Opera is crowded & one of the opera singers sing to crowds ending up with Marseillaise & crowd dont join in the chorus. How unlike Australia & this in the highly temperamental nation of France.

Everywhere street dancing is in progress. Wild groups dance hand in hand – carry the girls shoulder high & do all that the thousand & one mad freaks that can be done in moments of excitement – at 3-30 pm I have to lay down as my heart is giving signs of knocking up. 

I reach home about 7 am the following morning – tired & all that but still it is the only time that a peace like this will be signed in ones life & that one will be at Paris.

27-6-19

47

To night visited Montmartre – Café du Neant. Here there are coffins for tables & as each enters a funeral dirge is set up. Choose your coffin to right or to left everything is black & everyone addressed as Moribund.

After a while the taper which was given to you on entering dies out & you are dead. The lights go out & a purple ghastly light fills room from a glass tube. Pictures are then shown on wall which change before your eyes eg a picture of Messina & then earthquake & fire consuming the building & then above the ruins Death with his scythe.

The dance at Bal Tabarin with the figure of all turning to skeletons. We then pass through narrow & vaulted passages illuminated if at all by green ghastly lights. This passage leads into a vault where we are shown one of the audience transformed into a skelon – very well done as the face becomes very waxy & ghastly before the transformation

Then through outer vaulted to a churchyard where the seats are all tombs – Here on the stage revels are held – a fairy strips herself all but her chemise & after this we are sent out & told to let the moral sink in. The only moral I could see is dont die. 

From here Madelon & I 

went exploring & entered the Café d’ where visitor is hailed with jokes. 

Concert which lasts till 2 am is much the same as Chat Nour. Present proprietor has run show for years & has a red shirt & red collar. Mde takes no interest in show but busies herself among her accounts as if the air was congenial even necessary for complicated computations. Entrance fee is 1.60 & 75 centimes. 

After show at Madelon request we walk home even though the Metro were still running when we started.
Entry.36:
The day after peace – sleep till 11 am ie from 7 am & then get up & go to the races at Longschamp. 

This is the race of the year The Grand Prix of Paris & everyone is there. For my part there is too much of a crowd. Entrance is 25 fr & as my fortune is 48 fr I spend most in entering & looking at the wonderful dresses which only a Parisian could wear.

I succeed in losing on both my bets & return with only 15 francs to my name & not knowing where I can raise anymore. 

 Brisson has invited me to dine at her place to night & I get away from course after the Grand Prix which was won by an English horse Galloper Light owned by Rothschild

49

At 6 Ortolan St off Square Monge They are awaiting. Dinner is specially prepared I think Soup – spaghetti – tomato salade – rabbit – potatoes in kidney & gravy – with crème – biscuits fancy – coffee & wine (Graves).

After dinner I read some poems to improve my French & amuse them by my imitation of Goyard – They seem to think it rather good. I copy some pieces out & will learn them. She lends me her Larousse & L’Archeologie Egyptienne, & as I have a cold coming on she doctors me up with aspirin & an infusion.
Entry.37:
Wrote up diary & intended to go to bank but miss doing so. In afternoon I seek for but being unable to read Prof Truchi writing find myself in Rue Ponthien instead of Place 

Pontheon 

Visit Duke at 5 & ride in staff car to his home. After which I return to mine by metro. 

Metro here have no seats in some carriages & very few in the others. Each train of 5 carriages contains 1
Entry.38:
class car & as I am not a Frenchman ie I give my seat to any lady & will not seat myself so long as a lady is standing I generally stand & as often as not stand 2nd class for my boots are as comfortable in 2nd class as in 1st

The Frenchman is superficially polite but under the surface he lacks all the finer feeling for his women that we possess He will thrust her out of his way in a rush for seats. Never will he offer his seat to a lady. Women will offer their seats to crippled soldiers or women with baby in arms & occasionally a young man will do the same thing but this is rare. 

Fares in Metro are 30c & 20c. First class tickets are always inspected. All tickets are inspected as you enter platform & if 2nd class are never inspected again.

After dinner to night Clements intends to visit Nostre Rogis & I dig out Cailloud to accompany us. After a drink of wine in his atelier we set off & visit Nostre Logis 

Singing is exceptionally good this evening. Everyone seems to excel. Cailloud finds a modele & makes a appointment with her but he is like all Frenchmen never confident in a womans promise & says perhaps she will be there & perhaps not. 

After a while I try to sleep for 6 am very tired. In fact the sleeping fits that used to trouble at Woolwich seem to have returned. Perhaps it is weakness owing to lack of nutriment I have only 1 meal per day & in morning a little dry bread & cheese & water. This is my every day fare & perhaps is not sufficient but if I do not live in this manner I should have no money

51

on which to exist. 

We walk home again but this is a usual proceeding from Montmatre. Distance is 3 to 4 miles

1-7-19 (Tues)

Intended to go to a dance at Rue Tournon but as Mdlle Brisson has given me a invitation to a Bohemian evening I accept invitation & take Cailloud along with me 

We visit the rooms of some artist in rear of Hotel de Ville There is a piano in room & grand pianist is expected. Also a violiniste who has been all day at her examinations at Conservatoire. Neither however arrive but company composed of painter & artist with 3 girls from Gallerie La Fayette & a man & his wife who tells Fortunes & after that we have two animated discussions (1) as to whether & similar institutions represent the real Bohemian life at Paris (2) Spiritualism. But were very interesting & illuminating.

On way home I try to buy some bread & Brisson gives me a loaf & a tin of sardines at her home. The evening was indeed artiste & Bohemian & I look forward to a similar one
Entry.39:
Had an appointment for 2 pm with Madelon to visit Le Louvre but receive a 

note calling it off with the real reason given namely she wishes to spend the evening with an American officer who is leaving for America to night. Such candidness appeals to me. 

I visit Mdlle Hensson & find friends from Tahiti there. Mde Julien who knows Mde Tomel very well indeed & once made some trip with her. These people are very good & offer to get their son to buy my law books for me & the son makes an appointment the following day.

To day I visited M Chapries at Law School & find that I can pass my exams on producing certain certificates which I have left in England
Entry.40:
Visited bank this morning & find that after repaying money expended I have 246 fr (£8) to carry on with This places me on firm footing again for the other day all the money I possessed was 1 ½ francs & no opportunity of getting more even by borrowing although 2 ladies had offered to lend it to me

Believe the knowledge that you are without money in strange country & with no friends from whom you would care to borrow or ask for a meal is not a pleasant sensation

I call round to Hensson we go out to buy some books costing about

53

30 fr but by buying secondhand books as recent as the latest edition I save 10 francs on deal even though one book is new
Entry.41:
Fourth & though about 40,000 Americans in Paris day passes off without any demonstrations save a fireworks display at stadium 

I visit HQ to ask permission to visit England & find them just on Dinner. gives me a lift as far as hospital to visit a friend of his his Dr Shackleton for I have not been feeling well lately but he assures me nothing is wrong. 

I then visit the Masonic Headquarter Vicor Emmanuel III & register. Then not knowing what to do & hearing that Coghill is fighting to day I find myself at Stadium. Find it impossible to get in. Having met Nathan one of the teams at Viviennes or rather in an ambulance car which was going to stadium we try in vain to get in 

At last Nathan besieged a full colonel a APM & by his courtesy we get in & the stadium is a large oval in which several events are going on at same time The pavilions are all done in concrete & probably place will be permanent

To day Australia seems to be unlucky running into second place in nearly

every event America generally getting first place But result is not bad when you consider that our selection is from our little battle scarred army while Americas with her big conscripted population & also the fact that she has brought across from America about 70 competitor who have never seen France or the war seem to have been left long ago. 

Australia I think has proved her worth – Another item is that USA pays each competitor an allowance on which to train. Coghill who has run up to finals goes out on first round to Martin (USA) 

I meet Roy Hendy who is liaison officer. Also Solomons from Rose Bay & Hardwicke – I dine at camp at Hendys invitation & then come into town with Nathan & Coghill We intend to go to Opera but having changed cars about 5 times the last one finally breaks down & we are miles too late for Opera. 

We visit Montmartre which is now a crowded alley of all sorts of side shows, merrygorounds & a crowd in which it is impossible to move After a while we enter Elysee where there is dancing & skating. One of party wishing to see a cabaret artistique I take him to Neant which I have described before. After which I leave party & come home. 

So ended the 4/7/19 for

55

which I had made no arrangements 
but
 & though I tried to meet my American friend failed yet spent a very interesting day
Entry.42:
Met Madelon this afternoon at 2 pm also her friend. We were going to Louvre but day is so inviting that we change our plans & visit St Cloud the chateau of which was destroyed in 1870 by the Germans. 

The lawns are not green & springy but rather neglected. The grounds are exquisite long shady avenues & quiet rotunda in the basin of the fountain you find a reflection prettier even than the trees themselves. I have bought 21 pc 
about
 of this spot & they describe place much better than pen. 

We see some chairs on top of Trocadero – the Emperors private garden & go up & seat ourselves Soon after a young women comes along & demands 10c each though there was no notice to show that chairs were not public property. Any how the view was worth the 10c & we sat there for over an hour overlooking Bois de Boulogne & Paris. 

Then we wander through the private garden where no artificial lines hurt the eye. The garden is a rustic wilderness with a lake & kiosk

& a view that covers city & forest. 

About 7 pm I return to meet Hendy Hotel Continental (expense (1500 to 2000 for 15 days) & have an oporto, accompany him to his room & then find I am too late to get dinner in my old haunts. 

I choose an American grill room at the cheapest looking place hereabout. When I enter the lady in charge shakes hands. This seems ominous. I have chicken & rice & bread & cheese, no wine only water Bill 8.50 fr + 80 fr tip – Ice cream costs 3 fr Salmon Mayonaise 7.50. Such is the price one pays in the city. It is a big expenditure for me if I desire to return to England & purchase some clothes.
Entry.43:
Can get to sleep till nearly 4 At 5 am some mad singing enthusiast commence his practices. A funeral goes by then morning most of the mourners are in their ordinary working dress. Some appear to have just quitted their work & without changing joined up This absence of dress is very noticeable especially when going for an evening stroll round about home. 

Tonight I dined with Mde Brisson. Soup Vermicelli fish & lobster, beef – beans – cheese & cream – fruit with wine & coffee & yet these are poor people After dinner we talked & I left fairly early for I am not in best of health

57

but am always sleepy. I think it is the lack of exercise
Entry.44: Slept till 3 this afternoon although I was in bed by 12. Wrote letters & then to Windsor where I posted them – then took a warm bath at Florida Hotel Rue & then home to escort Marie Brisson for her first visit to Montmartre. I took her to Chat Nour & Neant & she was highly pleased.
Entry.45:
According to arrangement went to meet Nathan at Bal Tabarin in Rue Victor Masse This is large hall brilliantly lit balcony on one side & raised platform underneath it on other bar beyond both & at far end chairs & tables 

Impossible to remain single you are seized as soon as you enter. Floor is too crowded as a rule After while a quadrille is put – girls hold up their heavy & exaggerated petticoats as high as their shoulders all the time they are strutting about showing their unmentionables in all their piquant glory. Show rather disgusts me on the whole. Price entry 4.50 Drink 2.50 lemonade 2.50 Articles left in cloak room cost 25 cent each & Hat stick & coat costs 75c. Rather warm 

Nathan & Solomon both leave to morrow. Walked home for exercise of which

1) am not getting enough
Entry.46:
I have been invited to Volney Club 7 Rue Volney to night as the guest of M. Dolleans & meet quite a nice number of peoples. Dinner as usual is good 2 wines, Soup, Fish, Meat, Jalousie, liqueur & coffee & all for 11 fr. Ordinary meal is 7 fr 

After there is a pleasant concert & the girl who has gained the highest prize at Conservatoire this week plays on piano – a wonderful exhibition. 

The Frenchmen here are very interesting being the first Australian to be entertained by Club I am treated as a little hero & treated to champagne etc. & introduced to lady singers. Upstair I visited the gaming rooms. All French clubs are kept going by the gambling clique & play is always very high. 

I go home with & Dolleans promises to put me up as a non resident member but I do not accept for the present as I must consider expenses.
Entry.47:
From this date till 27-7-19 I have not written up anything and as in this period there was the French celebration of peace & national fete trip to Eng & peace celebrations there followed by a return & change of residence. 

As

59

much has occurred that it is almost impossible to remember what happened on the different days so much so that I cannot recall what I did on some dates.

This day I took Madelon to Sacre Coeur – Place – Madame Nini & Spanish Bar, & then walked home in the early hours of the morning
Entry.49:
Madelon has asked me to an afternoon tea that is given by herself & friends Besides myself there are 3 other men all Grecian but either naturlised or students one of them has been in French Air Service & carries a bracelet of thin gold chain which he says is distinguishing mark of Air Force. The refreshments are on luxurious scale for two students Conversation is ordinary. 

Madelon I think intended this to be a celebration of her exam which ended this morning but unfortunately she failed on the last day.

12-7-19

Slept nearly all day in order to get some sleep in hand as this is the commencement of the festivaties

amp; for the next three nights I do not go to sleep or to bed. 

This year the celebrations are united & combined with the official peace celebrations & you can imagine what days these will be – days that have been looked forward to during 5 years now. 

The streets are crowded & everyone seems to be out & as a crowd it is as good natured as one of our own but pulsing more with life. I was surrounded by a party of young imps all girls who whipped off my hat as a souvenir & when I pinned one of the girls as a hostage the hat was returned on condition that I kissed all the group, & they were so sprightly that I willingly paid toll & recovered my hat though it would have been returned with the kissing.

Only with difficulty can you get along the Grand Boulevards. Every taxi is surrounded & the crowd try to rock it till it capsizes but usually a gendarme arrives before this or the driver asks pity & they let him go. Often a crowd of 10 or more all sorts girls soldiers sailors foreigners (Americans or English or British) surround & dance in a circle round any one they meet. 

Everyone who can

61

play any instrument places himself freely at disposal of the crowd & whole crowd dances in sheer joy staid old age with boisterous youth. It matters little whether you have met your partner or whether you will ever see her again It is the pleasure of the moment which is passing & must be caught & lived ere it passes for ever

Towards 2 or 3 am the better class of people have gone home but the libertine & those whose trade it is to walk by night continue one.
Entry.50:
To night I decide to take Mdlle Brisson along with me She has been very good to me, asking me to dinner at her place, arranging Bohemian outings & getting tickets for concerts & as she cannot go out alone. 

After dining with her & her mother I take charge of operation show a parisienne who has passed 15 years in Paris; Paris I take tube to Obligades to see Arc de Triomphe from which these emotional people will break the chains which has shut off this arch from traffic ever since their tragic defeat in 1870. 

Alongside or rather at this moment under the arch is a cenotaph erected as an altar to the

memory of those who have not returned from the war but whose memory this city places above all else on this day of rejoicing. The statue is only of wood & plaster but the entire city files past it in a silence that is heartrending.

The amount of black in the crowd & the homage paid to it no matter what the condition in life of the person is a tribute of never dying gratitudes to one who has lost some dear one for their liberty The spirit of is entirely absent in this vast crowd which has come to pay its homage to the immortal & nameless dead. 

This spirit of sadness seems to tinge all the festivities. Whether the losses are in every family or whether the cenotaph looming at top of Av. Champs Elysee is an ever silent reminder I know not but there is a sadness here which later in England I failed to detect. 

The tubes are packed & it took us nearly ½ hour to get on to the station & in the train – well ordinary trains are packed but to night sardines are not more tightly packed & the hot smell of the tube & the body smell of the crowd some of whom are country people is not the incense breath of Morn.

63

It is impossible to get near the cenotaph even though we have gone to Obligads to try so we decide to omit the ceremony religious in its nature & officiated by the highest dignatory in the land as the most fitting person to honour the fallen

We pass down the beflagged & bepoled avenue & looking back in the distance saw the enormous catafalque veil removed 8.30 enshroued in clouds of incense which while under the glare of strong electric lights seems clad in ghostly clouds. 

At Place de Concorde the fountains are playing & white green or red searchlights are played upon the pulsing water with an effect that is beautiful. 

Already at this time midnight nearly 1,000,000 people have taken up their positions along the route to see procession to morrow Chairs & food carried from home which sometimes is not to near. After crossing Rue de la Paix we enter the Boulevards in which some of the buildings are very well illuminated 

At several places there are open public balls orchestras provided by the State. At one of these the Bouise we visited. Every adjoining café with an eye to business has placed tables right up to middle & in one case across the road which now

has no traffic. 

Here I saw a one legged soldier looking mournfully on the hilarity & dancing & then go up & ask a girl for a dance & she pretending not to notice the wooden leg did a few slow turns with him for he had gained the right to such a small return at least that is how this pretty laughing little creature put it though he smiles were lost in tears as she spoke. 

We did not dance but moved on to Montmartre
Entry.51:
I have called this 14-7-19 but really there was no division line. I do not know where midnight found me. 

Montmartre ie Boul-Clichy, Rochechouart has been transformed into a pleasure ground. Side Show, shows for real champagne swings, aeroplanes, merrygorounds of all kinds from motor cars to pigs, steam swings, relics from Noumea. Every conceivable side show is there. 

We visit steam swings a contrivance which succeeded in frightening more girls than all other side shows combined & hence most popular. Ride last about 2 minutes & costs 1 fr Merrygorounds are usually hand propelled & cost 50c. The machine asks a pourboire but never gets any. 

The relics of torture were good but nothing from Noumea was visible though this is what attracted me. We saw pancakes

65

being made in street & bought & ate them. 

I may add that for to night I have taken off my belt & stars & appears as a real digger. 

When matters began to quieten a little here we descend to the Boulevards again & about 4.30 am I think breakfast would be nice & as I know a nice little restaurant in Rue Reelle which is open all night or at least in the early morning for Les Halles we go there only to find place crowded & that no more are being admitted

We try other places with same result & then adjourn to first to await our turn. Inside I sample the famous Soupe de l’oignon which is only bread soup with a concoction of cheese on top no onion is visible hence the name.

At 6 am I take a trip to see if it would be possible to see procession as Brise wishes to see it. To go along Boulevarde is absolutely impossible & as we are near end of route Champs Elysee is out of the question. 

Seeing the ground a little elevated some distance from curb with a street that has not been closed up. We take up our stand with 2 hours to wait for commencement of procession & another 2 hours before it reaches us & then it comes.

Marchhaux & all who have been or have done anything in this great struggle – one after the after – & the colours of all the regiments

some of the colours being only shreds. After a long gap came the British with the standards flaunting in the streets of this Paris the name of battles which have stopped the victorious career of a militant France & saved her from her own Prussianism. 

When all have passed we slowly or rather as fast as crowd permits us walk towards home finding a tram for Montrouge start somewhere on route we rush it & thanks to my strength get in though I strain one of my fingers in doing so

I take Brise home & have a meal at her place & return to my room for 2 hrs sleep if I can get them. Unfortunately I miss them as I have to meet Harrison a scotch officer at Pigalle Restaurant Place Pigalle. He is not there so I dine alone in one of the cafes on the Boul Clichy & leave before meal is half way through as service is too slow. Waiter reminds me of waiter in Merry Widow only he possesses more sense.

I turn torwards Montmartre Sacre Coeur to see fireworks & here again luck favours me Finding Sacre Coeur crowded I enter Parc St Pierre from the bottom – the only possible way I find out afterwards as everyone has gone to top first & cannot get down

I find a nice spot for a seat & a nice bush into which I can withdraw if it rains (as it subsequently does) Here I see all the successive points of

67

display, Point Neuf, Parc Mountsouris, Buttes Chaumont, the St Louis both points which to me resemble Hotel de Ville & Louvre. 

Such a display I have never seen, vast fountains of fire 300 or 400 ft high & continous for 15 minutes or so. The vast spidery webs like a gigantic spiders are glorious. The magnificent rocket displays grander than anything we have had out our way, are simple alongside the other displays. Never have I seen anything to equal it & probably never will again.

Below in square there are 30 or 40 thousand people waiting to see the display behind me at Sacre Coeur. From time to time the building is thrown in red by port fires & at others it is illuminated by 6 powerful held searchlights which are stationed here for display purposes

Earlier in night there was a sortege lumineux consisting of a torchlight processions with 800 soldiers bearing torches, bands etc being supplied it formed at Av. d’Antin thence Concorde, rue Rivoli, Chalelet, Pont au Change, Boul du Palais, St Michel, St Germain, Quart D’orsay & Pont Alexandre. There has been one for peace & peace signatures & are always difficult to approach on account of crowds. 

At 1:0 pm there was a Fete in Tuilueries with concerts & country dancing & at 8 pm a free operatic display at Arenes de Lutece

a name which recalls Roman occupation

After quitting Montmartre I descend to the Boulevards & dance, gambol carry girls on my shoulder & generally act like a school kid till I am too exhausted to carry on & wander home at 8 pm. Eiffel Tour & Panthion with port fires & winds streaking it into layers – beautiful
Entry.52: Can recall what happened to day
Entry.53:
Went to GHQ & saw Harrison & got leave to go to UK & am leaving at 11.15 pm to night. With Harrison visited canteen, then to RTU & then home to pack up prior to leaving. I am dining to night at Volney Club (11 fr 50) & draw money. 

In street Madelin de Neef meets me & as she is looking for a house I assist her giving her a list of names & escorting her to many of them myself. She gives me a letter to Molle Gallagher Tavistock Square London in case I can not get a room. 

I dine at our little café & then adjourn to La Source et the Grand & get train at 11.15 pm with a compartment to myself & another man, so I can stretch out & go to sleep.
Entry.54:
Train was due to arrive in Boulogne

69

at 6.30 but at 6 am it is at Abbeville A wool administrator a Miss Tompkins from Yorshire joins us in carriage. 

On arrival I find that early boat is postponed till 12.30 on account of victory troops going across. When I come for my ticket there is some trouble as MLO wants the authority. I do not argue & then WO at gangway will not let me on board & then I return to MLO & get a return ticket & all is now well.

Biarritz pushes off about 2 pm & we get to Dover at 4.15. I am unable to buy any pc of Dover as the train meets the boat & the town is about 2 miles away. Dover is a harbour that has been erected at an enormous expenditure of money with too small openings for vessels. Within there is a fair amount of water. Over all on the hill is the old castle of Dover & outside the harbour the German wreck that I saw when I first entered the channel 

I arrive in London about 6.21 & find that in spite of crowded condition of London I can still get room here though I may have to sleep one night on a stretcher.

18-7-19

I forgot to mention that object of my visit to London is to obtain a certificate of my university degrees which are in my trunk at Kit Store for if I can

produce some evidence to Minister of Education I will be able to sit for degree of LLB – a two years course & I have 8 mos to take it & the exam is oral & in french 

So first visit I make is to Kit Store get the certificate – my coco palm walking stick & several things of use to me & then back to town – to Bank & draw all I have £16 leaving 30/- in Bank. This is all my reserve.

I then visit Alcock but they are closed. I then make arrangement to repair my stick & have job finished to day as I intend to leave London Saturday night if I can get all done. 

I see & French contingent arrive & then at Moss find that a ready to wear uniform costs 7 ½ gns. I visit & buy some puttees, collars shoes (17/6) & then Myers Tunic & slacks £2-10-0 Buttons must be changed etc but still a great saving. Then to Dean & annex a civilian suit for £5 & hat 4/6. In Strand I got silk faced white shirt for 8/6 & repairs to walking stick cost 2/6. 

As I can move quicker without parcels I adopt plan of buying & leaving parcels & of course fail to collect one worth £2-9-0 a havresack with puttees etc. This means that I must wait till Monday, & pay for two days extra here & in France. However it is better to do this than lose £2-9-0

I dine to night as usual in Soho

71

& to night at Restaurant Dieppe the only one I can find open. It is next to Au Petit Riche. Here I make friends with a Bank clerk from Lloyds Bank. Two French soldiers of the visiting contingent are being entertained by French party & the restaurateurs.
