In return the soldiers sing songs & one of them has an exceptionally fine voice which makes the evening pass very agreeably until
Entry.55:
pm
 1 am when I start for last tube
Entry.56:
This is the English date for the official celebrations of the Peace There is to be a procession similar to that at Paris but this of course will be mainly English – a tribute by the British nation to the victorious heroes. For this reason, Foch would not come across thinking he might detract from Haig’s triumph a thoughtful & kindly act I think but is prevailed upon to come. 

At Paris procession started 8-20 here at 10 am. At both cases it took about 2 hrs to pass. I have wonderful luck at 9 am I am in bed & at 10.15 am I am looking at procession from a position that many who have waited several hours cannot better 

or equal. 

It happened like this I was too late to be certain that buses would get as far as Whitehall so I went for Tube. There was a big crush but I got in & in train some gent whose little boy I had saved from being crushed advises me to go to St James Park which is inside the ring which procession makes & hence after this train is out of bounds This reasoning is good & we get an excellent view in Rochester Row.

Her Navy marches first after the visiting contingents of course Haig is very pale & as it turns out afterward is very ill. After all has passed I try to get out but policeman says only way is by ‘plane but if I wait an hour at Tube station I may get in. 

As I want something to eat having missed my breakfast I decide to wait but imagine my surprise when I walk right in. Everybody has expected the crush & avoided it. I reach town long before procession has reach town & dine in comfort as all the world is still looking at the procession. 

At 2 pm there are several concerts in Hyde Park & rustic dancing including a revival of the old English dances

At 7 pm there is a choir of 10,000 which perform in Hyde Park 

I dine tonight at Pinveli & lucky to get in as special dinners are being given in every cafés called Victory dinners & every table has been booked for weeks ahead. 

I meet an Englishman & his wife John O. Mayes of Constantia, Cienfuegos Cuba & now of Overseas Club, Aldwych London) & we join up in order to get in as there is a table for 3 available.

Inside all is a wild scene of revelry. A party of RAF & WRAF in one corner 2 opera or theatrical singers near by a Belgian woman & her husband a spanish lady all more or less half seas over & all making the greatest possible amount of noise. 

We order a boule of Chianti not knowing what a bottle is & behold a bottle which takes both hands to hold & about 18 in high arrives. Much excitement is caused by its arrival & many participate in its contents. One Aussie from Egypt a law student from Adelaide nips me for 10/-. 

Fun runs high & I did all sorts of things like the rest. Autographs are frequently collected & 2 chaps collect me & we do a forward rush down room clearing all before us including tables

Leaving here for the streets I encountered such an infernal din as I never heard before. Every kind of noise making instrument seemed to have been concentrated in streets & whistles & etc add to enlivement. voices are too weak to be heard in the din 

The fireworks display contains fire portraits of King & Queen & beautiful rocket displays but cannot equal the display on the other side of the channel. Then English display cost £20,000 the other must has cost £100,000 or more 

As room is not certain to night & stretcher is all I can expect I do not go home but try RAC & am advised to go to Savoy Baths which I do. This is really a Turkish Baths but the cubicles used to recline on are used for sleeping apartments by night, a cooker is kept on premises & breakfast can be obtained so it is as good as an hotel. 

My word I have slept in some queer places since leaving Aussie.
Entry.57:
Leaving Baths at 12 30, I do not know what to do & decide to visit Madelins friend Miss Gallagher & 

73

find her to be an exceptionally pretty & entertaining young person so much so that I invite her to spend the afternoon with me. 

We visit the Angels at Selfridge guarding 3 figures of soldier sailor & airman We then visit the Imperial room of Trocadero & find nice music & nice refreshments & fruit salad served for 2/6 apiece & we have an interesting talk. I see her home & she invites me to supper & after a talk I leave her promising to call again in November but most likely shall never see her again
Entry.58:
Spent morning collecting my goods & find at Railway that to go to France via Dover & Calais I must wait till to morrow at 7.50 am

In the evening I take a girl Lily Brooks who is staying in house to see decorations & illuminations. We commence at Constitution Hill & then to Palace & the Mall. The route here is lined with columns of plaster & on each amid a group of flags (allied) is the crest of some British Regiments, & in front of Palace four square columns with 112 of the big battles of the campaign 

How would the Americans get on with their stars on the ribbons

with numbers like this Illuminations there are none for the electricians have gone on strike. The decorations are I think better than those of Paris & some of the private firms are excellent eg Frascatis & Army & Navy

After supper at the Strand we adjourn home. 

There was one thing that I liked about the French procession & that was that in front of all marcher were wheeled a 1000 war cripples. This had no counterpart in England but seats in the Mall were assigned to widows & orphans, to Chelsea pensioners to wounded soldiers & to school children. In France school children were provided for but I dont know about the others. Seats were made of empty ammunition boxes. Some was done at Paris I find
Entry.59:
Rose at 5-30 am this morning & breakfast was ready for me & Lily was waiting to say good bye. This will be the last time I shall see her as she is being married on Bank holiday. 

I get a good seat & run into Folkestone at 10 am By mistake of MLO I get on Boulogne boat & dont bother to change when I see Calais boat or tub, a Belgian affair. MLO tells me I can run

75

up to Calais by train. 

Arrived at Boulogne entering stern first as usual. Passage has been slightly rough but everyone has been sick Arrived in Boulogne I invent a story about my luggage having been put on the other boat & get a free railway pass to Calais.

Train leaves at 2 am & is 2 hours late. It arrives in Calais to let me have a good look round I have travelled up with an English sister stationed for 2 years in Calais & she puts me wise to best way of seeing . 

I visit Bassin des Chasses a pretty lake full of boats & life separated from sea by a narrow stretch of sand. Place Richelieu with its Bourgeois de Calais by Rodin taken away & packed in a cave below Musee thence Place D’Armes with it beautiful old Musee once the Hotel de Ville

The Garden Richelieu I forgot to mention a pretty piece of rustic wildness – the Esplanade now filled with huts & an army transport centre & citadelle in rear. The old Notre Dame seems to me to have been a castle as well as a church for the surrounding wall & a gate is certainly not clerical. It is situated in a very dirty & secluded quarter hemmed in by dirty buildings

Everything here seems to have 

suffered from the bombardments & still mark the place where war has been. On other side of Town Boul Jacquart passing Place Centrale & Parc de St Pierre passes the markets & leads up to Theatre a fine building with a statue of Jacquart in front of it

I dine at Club but being among English officers do not say one word to anyone such is my admiration of English manner that I have adopted them with English men. 

I get train for Paris at 10.30 pm & find myself in compartment with Mdlle a descendant of the poet & a nurse residing temporarily at 
Sceaux
 Rue Amyot but actually at Sceaux
Entry.60:
After a pleasant night in the train I arrive in Paris at 7.15 & after putting my luggage in cloak room go straight to Brise No 6 in Rue Ortolan & breakfast there. 

We then start out to get key of my new abode but find that Marie Le Breton is out. Key is to be left at Concierge but is not there so we search restaurant, her home, but not till nearly 5 pm do we get key, having spent afternoon

77

in a picture show, the cheapest part of which usually costs 3 francs here. 

Room is a chaos of disorder but Brise is a gem & soon place is straight enough to sleep in. I dine with Brise & then collect baggage from Gare du Nord, & then see Brise home.

On the afternoon I had collected baggage from Marignon & said good bye to Rue du Sommerard. Although I had given over my room 5 days before leaving yet lady refused to let me have one night in addition & I told the maid she might have compromised
Entry.61:
Rose 9 am & at 9.30 Brise arrived with cheese, bread, coffee, milk etc & went out for warm milk. We start in to clean up & in course of a thorough search find punaise in the divan. This causes great consternation & energetic measures are taken 

Brise is desolated for she has found these rooms for me & is ashamed of her recommendation I on the other hand am quite pleased
Entry.62:
Brise arrives early again armed

with no end of death dealing liquids & also food supplies. After cleaning is finished she buys some meat & cooks it & we dine together She stays the afternoon & I go to her place for dinner. 

After dinner we go for a walk in the Bois des Boulogne, but it is late when we arrive there 10.30 pm. We encounter groups of men who apparent aim is to waylay anyone they can catch but on two occasions when I wheeled on them they did not seem to like my manner & cleared off in one case without waiting to answer my query.
Entry.63: Another I have lost at Montesquare Huesson & arrangement for Monday
Entry.64:
Expected Le Neef but she did not arrive. 

Brise blew in & wanted me to dine with her. 

Visited Le Neef but she is out & then went onto Montmatre to search for Mde Nini in Rue Norvius but dined at Place du Tertre in the public square It is deliciously fresh but one time I would not have eaten in public. Farmers used to worry me Dinner cost 7.30

If wine is not taken the profit is

79

added to the bill as a supplement. I visited Nostre Logis but found no one there whom I knew.
Entry.65:
Went to visit Harrison & then to Canteen where I made purchase amount to 27 fr then to see Shackleton but he will not be there an address is given 13 Rue Marche du St Honore & I pick up driver looking for him & ride along with him. 

Meet Shackleton & arrange to see him to morrow at Pepiniere Barracks Place St Augustin at 10 am rather early for me. Then dine with Brise & take her to No 2 Rue Brown Sequard & we pass a pleasant evening with the Gamels & the Huesson who drops in.
Entry.66:
Reach home at midnight & find parcel Brise has left for me contains sweetmeats as a birthday present. 

Yesterday I got a packet from Australia containing my pyjama 2 handkerchief & some chocolates & so the first thing I did after reaching home was to eat some of the two chocolates & sleep in pyjama & think of home Was it not lucky to arrive at such

an opportune moment

In morning I visited Barrack but Shakleton is not there However by waiting for a car I make the acquaintance of Whelton an Irish in Air Force & he invites me out to lunch at Buc. The drive out there through the Bois di Boulogne then St Cloud & Versailles is beautiful. These parks would be worth being a monarch for even if once in a while some one more unfortunate than the others lost his head. 

I spend day at Buc & then return in a ambulance waggon which travels at 40 miles an hour most of time to amazement of all French police but being military they do not interfere. 

We go to Nord & then in Champs Elysee have an accident in which a gendarme narrowly escapes being killed This delays us for some time & we have to run him to a place where he can put his bicycle However we part the best of friends & he will claim against John Bull & some day will be paid perhaps.

After dining in a little place in Rue Pergolese

81

We hit the trail for Montmatre & commence a series of wild drivings with a madman at the wheel who can not drive under 30 miles an hour & so never can turn at proper turnings & is so far past when he can pull up that we have no idea of proper turn. 

We go from Boulevard to & finally pick up two girls & spend night in Senga – a dancing cabaret & finally dropping girls one an Algerian & the other a Belge but both speaking Russian fluently at their homes promising to meet them at Taverne de Paris Aven. Clichy. 

Such was history of my birthday. Rather a rapid one
Entry.67: Cleaning up again & finally declare place clean. Brise cooks dinner & dines with me & then I go to her place for dinner. Where she puts buttons on my new coat & sews up pockets, after a vain attempt to blacken the buttons
Entry.68: Study all day & make some progress Have warm bath in evening
Entry.69:
Same story. Marie Le Breton

visits me to day to see if I am quite comfortable. This is her rooms & she is letting me have them for 30 francs a month seems too good to be true.
Entry.70: Brise arrives this morning & spends all the morning cleaning up & disinfecting place. She brings me hot café au lait. I can keep rooms for as long as I remain here – The price is 25 fr per month only, & with Marie Le Bretons furniture it is very chic.
Entry.71:
Make arrangements to take Brise out for the afternoon. We go to Cimitiere Pere La Chaise. Originally the gardens & grounds of the confessor of Louis XIII & now the resting of the Parisian dead, not of the famous dead for a special place The Pantheon has been reserved for them but so far not many, for it commenced only with Mirabeau. Pere La Chaise contains all prior to that date.

We talk of Rookwood as a city of the dead but it is a wilderness to this city of the dead when the dead are crowded as thickly as the living in tenements, so much so

83

that as the price for a concession a is so dear that you can buy a tomb for 30 years or less & at end of time boxes are removed to make room for others. 

Often the cover of a tomb is opened to let air in or stink out. I dont know which I suppose the system of embalming is up to their ordinary standards in hygiene. I looked down several & found them to be walled in down to 20 or 30 ft & at sides & on crevices were masques apparently of inmates who rest somewhere below perhaps near Australia. 

The monument aux morts is an impressive affair. A void towards which suffering humanity whilst two lovers are passing over threshold. Below the angel of immortality shows a family whom death has reunited But it would have been better if this lower group had been the other side of the veil. 

Above that is the Chapelle from the terrace in front of which a beautifull panorama of the city unfold itself Quite close is a with a dominating figure of Casimir Perrier whose head is surrounded by a swarm of bees or flies. 

Trees abound everywhere & one is almost always in the shades among the shades. The magnifence of some of the tombs eg the Demidoffs is beyond any description. Fontaine & Molier rest in same tomb. 

Amongst the tomb in older part of cemetery that

of the tragedian Talma with just this one word on it. This part of cemetry is a closely packed system of vaults all above 10 ft high & all under shade. It is as the city of the honoured & ancient dead for most of the old families & well known personages are envaulted here. 

Further on we pass to the crematory with its arcade for the ashes which has been cheapened by arranging flowers most of which die in a few hours & the appearance is worse than if they had never been placed there. 

Thence on to Musselman cemetery enclosed with a little hedge & finally out. Of some of principal graves I have purchased some pc from a woman the chapel whose clothes reeked of human corruption I dont know how she stood it but I had to get out in fresh air. I dont mind visiting a cemetery but I dont wish to caress & commune with the putrefied remains of what was once humanity. 

Leaving here we visited Notre Dame de la Croix it was closed. We then went up Menil Montant to Buttes Chaumont once a disused quarry & garbage tip but now transformed into a glorious park with walk, grottoes, cascades & a lake. 

From a temple on island a glorious panorame of the N.W & beyond of Paris unfolds itself though the city is veiled & must be seen

85

from other side of Parc. Thence home to Mde Brisson where I dined & then sat up all night with a sick friend
Entry.72: I am ill & cant walk – lay up & do nothing
Entry.74: Still the same – am attended on almost night & day with an attention that is beyond comprehension till secret is revealed
Entry.75:
Still the same – state – if matters do not improve I shall have to call in a Doctor. 

To night my little friend who has wished to give me a substantial birthday present has invited me to Opera Comique where one plays what is known as Grand Opera which here is reserved for the Opera. The seats are excellent & cost only 10 fr but there is a box for poor, a war tax – a supplement – 2 fr for booking & in sum one pays 15 francs.

The theatre is like that at Bruselles – gilt everywhere Piece is Manon & some of singers are excellent though the best have left the city in this hot weather. It is like

our spring. The foyer is large but the balcon open on the rue & has little attraction except for smokers. Most of world promenades in foyer & I limp there also. My leg is now very painful.
Entry.76:
Pay a visit to M. Petit Dupalle re my certificate but he is out & I arrange to see him to morrow. (When however I am to ill to move) 

I then visit garden & Musee de Luxembourg with its wonderful statuary though one can find fault with much that is there In fact it turns out that is not the by which one is placed in Luxemburg but rather 

The paintings are removed in place to an exhibition of Carolus Duran whose early painting, The Dame au gant (1848) are the best. The finest picture in collection is a painting of Duran himself by one of his pupils an 
Englishman
 American named John S Sargent. It is a masterpiece & puts to shame the rest of the collection. I should very much like to see more of Sergents work.

After this we reached the Church of St Sulpice in front of which is the Square St Sulpice with it fountain supported by the 4 leading preachers of France & alongside The Seminaire du St Sulpice where one of the acts of Manon has peace. The church is in Renaissance style – a roomy edifice once a Temple of Victory in times 

87

of Convention & the scene of a dinner party to General Bonaparte. The frescoes are excellent though some are showing signs of wear The altar & pulpit are best described by reference to pc which I have forwarded. There is a meridan line in this church but I forgot to notice it. 

After this I returned to Rue Delambre a pied The day was rather too much for me
Entry.77: Repose all day headache – fever, glanular swellings –
Entry.78:
Toss about all day. Brise makes many trips per day & suggest that I rest at her home where I can be looked after. It will save her an hours walk 2 or 3 times per day & she will call in her doctor. If I am no better I have decided to this 

Tonight we went to Odeon one of the 4 theatres subsided by Govt entirely (Opera, Comedie Francaise & Palais Royal being the other). Drama was L’Arlesienne. The music by Bezet was excellent. Orchestra had 14 violins alone The acting was good but at times a little tedious. It needed a Pauline Frederic to play one part & she was not in cast. 

After theatre as I am still ill, I take taxi home to her place & put in a miserable night. Brise pleading to for me
Entry.79: Dr came to day & so expect relief tonight All the day is spend in bed. I have a tonic to take & poultices & hot compress
Entry.80:
All day in bed waited on hand & foot by Brise who is making a slave of herself for me, nothing is too much no journey is too long. Food is her greatest worry what will please me most & in these day there are big food troubles

First the consumers refuse to buy then the suppliers refuse to supply Often she has long walks to get anything & all the while humping the big load she has already bought. She has a heart of gold, & that refined.
Entry.81: Still in bed but making great strides towards recovery. Still the same patient & careful attention. Was ever man so carefully & thoughtfully tended I wonder A cousin arrives & stays the night
Entry.82: Recovery is rapid. I do not put foot to ground. Breakfast is shared on the bed with me. Now I change rooms at night for the two girls. Tomorrow is Brises fete & she is the recipient of many flowers & letters & a Salome by Wilde.
Entry.83:
Fete de l’Assomption – a great day & once Napoleons day but now used by worn out city people to take a holiday into the country & owing to the rush the papers wisely comment that those who stay in the city show best sense for the struggle to get away is too much. 

Save for Church services 

89

there is nothing doing & though I am sure I can walk without detriment I remain within. At night Marie Le Breton & her husband come to dinner. 

They have seen Paris. It is absolutely deserted & the papers have pictures showing the places ordinarily thronged with people without a single person or vehicles visible. – A scene of desolation & the photos are taken at 2 pm & onwards & the photo are those that are taken in an ordinary stroll. 

So I have not missed much by staying in.
Entry.84:
Life at Rue Ortalon is very pleasant I pass all day in pyjamas & study all the time Meals are provided without waste of time by hands that 
are
 only ask the right to do something Life has its charm. 

All tenements a little court. Everyone is curious – & every one is talkative No one cares who overhears or oversees them. There is no such element as self consciousness, & often their language is not classical. 

One family below take their meals where all can see & hear them accompanied by 4 cats 2 rabbits 2 dogs & other animals all running loose. To back is a collection of slums patched up by rags & temporary makeshifts & filled with a population whose chief characteristics are age & filth, & into whose daily habits you can inspect. There are some children aged about 10 though how they have survived so long. Goodness knows. 

To left is Rue , a street which contracts to 7 ft wide for almost ½ its length & has railed balconies

of the part where the houses were built before the level of street was taken & still exist at night, the street is alive with rats. In fact almost any street in Paris has its rats by night owing to garbage systems. 

Garbage here are placed out in street at night & are then visited by cheffoniers miserable creatures half human who overall the garbage for & do not pick up the litter they have made. The garbage cart comes along some time before the morning. No wonder the plagues used to kill off Europe 600 yrs ago when sanitary conditions were not so good or rather less worse.

In Rue Monge coming home one night with a girl time 9 or just after dusk, an old dame rushed ahead into first doorway – it was closed – & standing upright soon a sound of rushing water was heard & the old dame laughs & made some remark. No sense of shame though my companion was overwhelmed.
Entry.85: Leg is better – study is going good & I have half made up my mind to take the licence – ie to do 3 years work in 6 weeks rather a tall order & too big I am afraid. However I will make up my mind later
Entry.86:
Make my first visit out to day but avoid walking as much as possible. These avenues are simply glorious with their shaded walks of trees. Raspail has an avenue down the centre of itself & every few yard a bed of flowers

91

or shrubs. Montparnasse has its acacia trees on the footpath a row on either side. The streets are constantly watered & there is a freshness in the air that reminds one of the country even in this overcrowded city.

I find disappointment everywhere. Petit Dutailles is on leave. No letter at bank – a shop where I wished to buy pc closed – a difficulty looming to obtain the books requisite for my study, & there will be no dinner at Cercle Volney
Entry.87:
Same story of care & attention & study 

In the night we take a stroll to Parc Montsouris a pleasant little park just within the city walls the summit of which forms the country for the poorer class & they are legion in this quartier.
Entry.88:
This day as there is no Volney circle I accept an invitation to help celebrate the fete of St Jeanne chez Rue Merlin near Pere La Chaise though poor they do themselves well for the fete which is merely the saints day after whom you have been named. Wine is Chianti red & white & champagne to finish party is 6. Morel is a big cycle ride of some repute. 

We miss last metro connection but find a taxi (7 fr) It was a wild night.
Entry.89: Same story, study, sloth & attention. M. Arison & his daughter arrive to day. I am off colour
Entry.90: Ventured out again to find some information re this Dutailles who seems to me a bit of a humbug. I find that I must make the application. I could have & would have done this 4 weeks ago if Dutailles had not appeared on the scene. I walk thro garden du Luxembourg & thence to Rue Ortalon.
Entry.91: Rise late – cant study – write letters to M C Ministre who they say is to be the next president. I am alone almost all day.
Entry.92:
Visit Versailles to day – rather late starting but get there at 2 pm. I have previously seen the grounds of the palace. The palais an enormous structure erected by Louis XIV or rather Levan & Mansart would cost to day £20,000,000 It has accomodation for 10,000 inmates rather a large family but then the King brought his Ministers & Parliament to be close to him for it was from here that Louis XIV directed the affaires of France during its most illustrous period. 

We entered the chamber of deputies but find that here even the French people are exploited for the benefit of the garden. People are grouped in a room to number of about 80 & then door is opened & you are led like a flock of sheep to room & on going out you move as a herd & pay something to the flunkey who opens the door. 

Being treated like this does not

93

accord with my tastes & I determine to leave visiting till another day. 

I pass along thro avenues of arched trees bordered by ivyclad wilderness till I reach the Grand Trianon. Yesterday was fete day of St Sidonie & the Roses of Trianon bring back memories. 

The building of which the columns are all red marble is one storied & extremely 
pleasant
 handsome while the gardens in front are a dream. The wooded walks & shaded avenues lead on to Hamlet of Marie Antoinette with its temple of Love & English gardens. 

If all the gardeners who throng the palais were put to the useful task of cleaning up the glades & drives & were put down the palais would be paradise.

We visit the Petit Trianon & then back to a tour of the fountains of the Palais. Next Sunday they will play & I will let you know more about them.
Entry.93:
Presented my demand for Equivalence to day to Monsieur (in full if you please) C Ministre de l’instruction Publique & continue to study But several things have been omitted. 

He requires proof that I have been born & says birth certificate must be produced. I point out Australia is more than 100 yds away & he says get a military certificate & get it legalised by British consul, & have translations of all certificates for this vast

department does not apparently possess one individual whose mental capacity is equal to the task of mastering the English language. Even in our Customs I used to interpret French certificates & did not insist that translations should be forwarded.

It is this official procedure which cripples commerce & civic relations in this country Never was there a country whrere Liberty means less especially as it figures everywhere alongside of Equality & Fraternite. Equality is non existent 
being
 the social gradations being changed for a hierachy of Officialdom & militarism.
Entry.95:
Obtain a certificate of birth from British AP.M. & demand a translation which gives me an introduction to the French liason officer a law student named Rochenback who gives me much information re law course. 

I visit consul to get certificate legalised. This consists in certifying to my signature & costs me 8.75 & a

95

wait of 2 hours even though I obtained a priority of admission over 50 or 60 who were waiting. Consulates are institutions formed by Govts to fleece its subjects found in a foreign country. If I were destitute I should never go near a consulate unless compelled. In N.C it was the same robbery.

It is this system of fleecing by ones own countryman I cannot understand. A foreigner has some right in his own country. Just imagine 875 f to verify a signature the work of 1 minute & work which any fool could do. The good that these institution do is annulled by the extortions they make. 

I then make my way to rue Grenelle where M. le Ministre has his bureau at 110. The building is absolutely destitute of human beings. Knowing where to go I enter a large room which a flunkey possesses to himself & leave my papers & call again in 15 days. 

On my way thither one circumstance amused me. I wanted to know way & looked for nearest policeman. I saw a senior officer in French army approach him, salute him, ask him way & resalute & go away. I did the same saluting act which is mere common politeness here. But fancy

saluting a policeman in George St. Sort of makes you think what Equality means here. 

Passing along Boulevard St Germain (which contains many princely mansions & courtyards which are lost by the system of building in that is rampant here) I notice several demolition for rebuilding purposes in each case there is a single wall between each property & not a wall to each house as we possess.

There is one thing I forgot to mention ie that cats are not expected to kill a rat. Any person claiming that his cat has killed a rat must produce the rat as evidence before he will be believed. What on earth they keep cats for in this rat infested city I do not know.

28, 29. 
& 30
 

Lost days –
Entry.96:
()

Intended to see the Grands at Versailles in the afternoon but a heavy thunderstorm decided me to remain away

of living softened & cadenced by reason. 

Passing onwards & upwards to Escalier Daru rests the Victory of Samothrace without head or arm but yet of arresting workmanship – clothed in fine linen & not in heavy wrappings – Her marvellous body was not designed for daily tasks but was of the gods – a beauty that was in itself an ideal. Her movements though vigorous were always harmoniously balanced 

This the best somewhat dimmed the undoubted beauty of latter works but one in special took my fancy a light & almost living figure in bronze another was the Young Neapolitan by Rude a child with laughing face playing with a tortoise.

All the picture were not yet in their place Titian & the school are missing But Van Eyck, Rembrandt & who can write of the play of light & shade that the master has shown in the two philosophers. Alone in the centre of a room stands Mona Lisa with her mystic smile of ever bewildering fascination. 

In one of the by itself is a small statute not 3 ft high of a young boy called L’Ephebe

99

attribute to Andrea Sansovino circa
Entry.97:
siecle but whoever be the author its beauty & surpassing excellence render it worthy of Praxiteles himself. To my mind it equals the ancient Greek – Every line & muscle on the body is true to life & the grace & freedom of action render the child alive.

Of the many wonders the place contains I cannot write but I return again & perhaps many times ere I leave Paris.
Entry.98:
Visited Bank & found education inspector had gone & then home to find whole place rather awkward as I was accompanied

3,3,4 lost days
Entry.99:
Brise has gone to Marie Le Bretons & I am alone all day but meals have been prepared for me. Veal roasted in its own humidity & blood gravy in jelly when cold. 

To night is just type of night for reverie all the neighbours are still out & a band in Place Monge sends measured cadences of melody across slum that now are picturesque in the golden moonlight. 

The moon which can ever make beautiful

the slum of the Latin Quarter & Rue St Medard while in the shadow of it attracted by its pure rays two little waif have crept from the bundle of rags to the windows & in whisper are telling each other something – & the happy & innocent thrill in the tone makes me wonder if money is worth seeking if it give not happiness for these children of poverty (& I know what it is for I can see into their rooms) have something in their voices that is lacking from mine, perhaps because life in its unreality lies before them while to me all its illusions have faded. 

I wished to night I were like these children
Entry.100:
To day is the fete of St. Cloud & the fountains play to day & also on the 14-9-19 but after Versaille they are a poor show or rather are overshadowed by the number. One jet here rises to a height of 136 ft. 

In the afternoon or rather midday we start out for St. Denis the burial place of most of the French Kings The façade built in 1140 preserves the old pre Gothic arch while the battlements along the top were built for other than peaceful pursuits. 

The French king from Dagolert 1 (638 AD) to the Last Louis are nearly all interred here with the relics of St Denis. Tomb of Henry IIX Catherine de

101

Medici is a masterpiece by Pierre Lescot but the old dame not relishing the propriety of being shown in the nude created another tomb or effigy showing herself & husband clothed. 

Tomb of Francois 1 also merits attention with black marble in top & sculptured in the marble the tombs of Marignam & Ceresole. Behind by Pierre Bontemp is an urn containing his heart. On the crypt is the burial vault of the Bourbons. 

Taking train we went on to Enghien where we wandered through vegetable gardens until one found one of Brise friends Alece & her husband. Here we were invited to stay for dinner. Women wages pre war at highest was 7 f per day This railway employee 3 fr 50 per day passes for himself & family.

Thence we set out for Montmorency & its forest. associations of JJ Rousseau. The view from the terrace of the church is very fine. The town is very old & some of its streets are fully 4 to 6 ft wide & often so steep that the authorities have placed a handrail along the building to support you in the task of ascending the street.

The Mairie Arts park reminds one of a little chateau de Trianon & is exceedingly artistic We overlook the Orangerie & enter the Chataignerie but this is for most part dotted with building & the ancient

forest has to a large extent ceased to exist. Much has been cut down during the war & also for defensive purposes as the wood contains Montmorency & Montlegnon two of the outer ring of of Paris. Rousseau sheltering place is in Rue Gretry which we entered in error. 

A cafe called the Ermitage was our aim in Boul. d. l’Ermitage we return to chez abel & pass a pleasant evening & then set off for Lake Enghien (1/2 M by ¼ mile). 

The edge of the lake is fringed with the houses of the noveau riche of Napoleonic times but very beautiful. One in particular took my fancy & I may reproduce it in my chateau. 

The avenue forms a pleasant wooded walk especially on such a night as this is. Calm & peaceful with a full moon – the moon whose silver rays can lend enchantment to any scene & which gloss & beautify what the glaring light of unsympathetic day only reveals in its squalor. 

On the banks of the lac stand the great Casino where life & gambling run high. Now it stands a white skeleton in the moonlight – a souvenir of remembrance of the devasting influence of war for it has not opened its door & the myriad lights that once shone in its gardens are now extinguished soon however it may re open

103
Entry.101:
Some few things that strike me as peculiar which came under my notice this morning. Here in Paris there are still town criers & with a bell to announce facts to populace Men bearing placards – – walk along all day in the street though not to same extent as in London.

Police here all carry a useless bayonet & even on hot days a cape overcoat. In Paris itself many of the roads are rough cobble instead of wooden blocks & makes omnibus travelling very uncomfortable. 

I have lately commenced to eat horseflesh & like it better than beef. I commenced with a fillet of steak both at same time – one bite of horse & one of bullock & I prefer horse It is tenderer & much cheaper. 

Prices here are exhorbitant. A Commission has just been formed which regulate the prices for the week & even so prices are high. Here are the prices of commission for
Entry.103:
(a Kilo = 2 ½ lb)

Butter 5.20 for ½ kilo

Eggs .50 each

Beef Filet 12.40 per kilo – Rumsteak 9.90

Porc Filet 12.30 – Hams 11 – trotter 2.40 an kilo

Veal Gigot 9.20 shoulder 7.10

Poulet per demi kilo 5.75 – Rabbit 2.25 3.30

These are best quality the lowest grade is always 2 francs cheaper.
Entry.104:
Visit Ministre & after met Mdlle & we sit & talk in garden near Palais 

About sundown the trees the leaves of which are already beginning to take their autumn tints a wonderful nuance of colour aided by a mist which in reality is only a shadow effect. At each instant the colour seems to change but only in shades. I shall for the future always have deciduous trees in my chateau grounds.
Entry.105:
At atelier of Mdlle Brisson with Mdlle Marga & after that to Luxembourg on far side near Rue Guynemer with Chopin monument near. The long lanes never straight in this part of garden 
all
 overshadowed walks & patches of bright flowers far surpass any garden I have seen & leave a memory of beauty that will always be present
Entry.106:
Fountainbleau – rise 6.30 & take our dinner provided by Brise a fowl a bottle of wine, fancy biscuits & cake & fruit, not bad for a rural dinner in the forest. 

We reach station & instead of going to town & chateau strike off in opposite direction the only ones to do so & as always untrodden paths are pleasantest we find a treasure trove

105

Tour Denefort which commands a view for nearly 40 miles around. Tour Eiffel can be seen in clear weather. 

Then we went round Butte a Guay under branching ardours & amid greens & mosses which in the early morning gave that delightful perfume of the bush. Then we reached Croix which overlooks town. Then striking through the forest & across the road we enter the park of the chateau & follow the ancient avenue of trees to the parterre which is not even imposing in its severity.

French gardens have no grace but are a series of straight lines at right angles to each other. The squareness of angles ones eyes accustomed to graceful lines & unexpected effects. 

The chateau is closed till 2 pm to enable the guardians to take their meals. The shift system being apparently unknown or rather in this country where beaurocracy has replaced autocracy it is a system to let people know that they are merely the people – the common herd. 

We searched vainly for a place to dejeune having passed so many little beauty spots in the forest. Happily we find the Plaines des which though surrounded by public roads 100 yds away yet is completely private. Then we visited chateau (of which pc best explain) with its wealth of Napoleone

records even to his hat.

Leaving the chateau & taking a pleasant beer beneath the shade of trees & refilling our wine bottle we wandered over sandy path with innumerable sign posts & directions which directed nowhere 

Intelligently we reach the grand Gorges de Franchard a collection of stones or pebbles in a gully not as deep as middle harbour – yet a Gorge – wonderful name. Franchard was an old hermit her in XII siecle & part of old monastery still remains & also his well (see pc)

After this Gorge & with a thunderstorm approaching & a 7 mile walk back to town I decide not to visit the Gorges of but finally take a look at them. The forest in the half light & after the shower is glorious especially the George du Houx.

We just catch a train & board train while in motion & finally reach after & finish chicken. Walked this day 28 KM – 17 ½ M
Entry.107: Went to Bouffe Parisien with Mdlle Marga & Mde & M Julien her tickets were wrongly dated & we spend evening in Grand Cafe regarding the life of Paris as it passes by & you cannot imagine how interesting it is
Entry.108:
107

Chantilly to day – the prettiest & most homely of all the chateaux. As usual I stray from beaten tracks & descend at Orry Coye. 

We are very late starting owing to having spent night previous at Montmartre & then to cap all having to take an omnibus train. 

The forest of Coye lightly timbered & yet completely shaded is a subject for a picture but what shall I say of the Pool & Chateau of the Queen Blanche. The small tower situated over falling cascades on to a velvet 
carpet
 tree covered carpet while a view of the railway viaduct of 15 arches towering overheard. 

The lake, down to edge of which the forest descend Coye on one side & 

Chantilly on other though really the same forest, is fringed with a road – forest on one hand & a hedge on the water side. Sunlight & then a heavy shower followed by a mist rising from lake makes varied pictures
Entry.109:
enraptured are we by the scene that we dine on rising ground in view of lake & chateau under an enormous elm & though rain is heavy & we have no macs we continue to dine well & dry on chicken & wine & cheese & cakes, while the million drops of gold splash on the gilded surface beneath us, & the air is full of that sweet odour of woods after april shower. 

This is the prettiest spot I found

in this fair land of France.

After a farewell look at the lac we trudge through the rain soaked forest along tracks that would have been sand but are fairly easy walking now. We pass a plantation of silver birch (boulean) & the series of silver trunk glistening in the sun add another note to this pleasant forest. 

In due course we land in the road that leads to castle, when suddenly in a little clearing in the woods we find the flotsam of the wave of war which passed by here in 1914 – a cemetery of the dead but only of men who fell here

The chateau is situated in a lake – part built in 1560 by Constable Anne de Montmorency whose stature adorns the entrance road – She is a man & the companion of 
Henri IV le Vert Galant
 Francois 1. 

It is famous in history for the brilliant fetes given by the Prince de Conde (the Grand Conde) whose maitre d’hotel Vatel committed suicide because the fish did not arrive for the feast given to Louis XIV It finally came in the possession of the a son of Louis Phillips who entered army as a private & became a – famous for his african campaigns – Dying he left the property to Institute of France together with the art treasures of his family. 

The collection of pictures is the finest for a private collection that I have seen including Rafaels Madonna of the Orleans family & The Three Grace a little work about 1 ft square containing figures of 3 naked women & yet in 1885 it was bought for £25,000 & is now without a price. There is also one of the earliest

111

French painting.

A Book of Hours or rather 40 miniatures from the Book of Hours by Jean Focquet in 1452-60. They cost £13,000. Also the banner taken at Rocroy (1643) the oldest military trophy in France. 

This chateau was occupied by the Germans in 1914 (It is only 25 miles from Paris) & after during the war by the French H.Q. Many of the musee & chateau are only recently opened & a visitor who has passed through France just after the armistice does not know what treasures he has missed.

I am writing this 20-30-20 & it was only the other day that the English & French school was opened at Louvre & the Dutch school is not yet opened. 

Then we visit the English garden – the Temple of Love but miss the Hamlet on the other side. Water is everywhere & fountains numerous. Many apparent alles are tree bordered strips of water, & then the parc de Silvie with its allees like cathedral aisles – the trunks & the overhead folige must have inspired many a church of the gotheque (or francais) order. 

Beautiful as this is yet nature has thought fit to embellish her handiwork & has put 
velvet
 plush along all the walks & the soft springing feel of these path with the vistas at the other ends often illumed by rays of sunshine.

If only I could possess such a parc no other place in the world would hold any charms for me, & then with the setting sun the of sunshine & shade falling through the forest – the opening clearing at end of allees & beneath the wealth of dead leaves in the

ever present heritage of a past that is dead but which is always with us. 

Sadly we quit this scene of beauty which perhaps I shall never again see but whose memory will for ever haunt me. We follow Route de l’Ayle to station passing the magnificent stables & the Grand Stands. A long wait for train & then a short run packed like sardines – debout – & thus ended one of the most beautiful days I have passed 
here
 in France.
Entry.110:
For the greater part all days & their events which follow so quickly here are forgotten. I have no record whatever of what I have done & I have copied the following dates from the journal of Maria who has noted those events which concerned us two. 

They are for the most part outings taken together on Sunday which I continued in spite even of exams I worked so hard till my exams that I never left my room 
till
 all the week & Sunday was the only break.

Usual routine was petit dejeuner 8 am coffee & rolls & butter (the rolls are long layers of crust) specially sought by loving hands when I broke my tooth on the ordinary kind. This petit dejeuner I take in bed. M. rises about 6 am to search the

113

milk for which she takes a place in the queue & how her health stands the strain of her work & the wait in the cold damp air of these dark winter morning with the snow on the ground passes my comprehesion I would have succumbed to it long ago She really possese a reserve of energy that if I could acquire I could be whatever I desired.

After breakfast I dress quickly in old clothes which I possess & a pair of Marie Lebretors slippers that I salvaged at my little chateau de 17 Rue Campagne Premier. Then I betake myself into bedroom with a blanket & hot water bottle or brick provided by Brise or her mother & dig into law then the hour of dejeuner (noon)

I am not called till the soup is even in the plate & then I am called. I might add that I am consulted as to if I am ready before meal is served. Everyone must speak in whispers & tread on tip toe if I am working. A King could not be better served. 

A wish is always interpreted as an order & obeyed as such. The food I eat is chosen If I once refuse a plat it never appears again. If I show a

.

preference it is often found on the table. I must not eat same dishes too often – Food is changed. If bilous certain vegetables or salades are bought. Expense is not considered & as you know prices are very high here. Sunday is always a feast. Fowl is always there (costing about 13/- a piece) & this is only a working girl who is sacrificing her all to give me pleasure.

She was very hurt when I told her that I would not stay in the house in spite of all her kindness if I could not contribute towards the expenses & until Nov. I was allowed to contribute my quota on a basis of a week when only current provision were bought. Coffee, sago, tapioca & all standards – like these were not included, & though prices doubled & trebled I was not allowed to change the basis.

Since Nov. I have been her guest & nothing can make her change this status; without her I never could have stood the & she has saved me perhaps 10,000 francs. When I was paying 12 franc a day for a room she found me furnished quarter 2 rooms rez de chausse – private cour – no concierge library for 25 frc a month. The price elsewhere would have been at least 800 to 1000 fr a month. 

Every day she came to bring me something that rooms lacked – a curtain of lace – oil for lamps – a knick knack – coffee hot in morning – she cleaned up the room & bought all my provisions for me

115

Sometimes twice a day she came across a trip of 1900M.? each way, ie 2 ½ miles – no joke for a frail little woman who after that walked all over Paris to find her work. 5 miles on to her days work & that for me. 

Sugar can not be bought but she gives me of her own store knowing that her ration tickets can not be given & it is a loss for her & her mother. She even gives me her kerosene because it is unprocurable. 

She cooks my meals – brings breakfasts & washes up all dishes. She visits chateau once a week to clean it up. Never have I found anyone who cared & looked after me so much. If a man can be bought surely she has bought me for never can I repay her. 

But to continue my story of study I return to my books with blanket (the old one) around my legs & my hands in my pockets to keep them warm. This continues till 7 pm when I adjourn to divan (& bed) when I linger over dinner till 9 pm & then to work again. 

Brise often sleeping & dozing alongside of me the little No noise is allowed & I commence to talk or chat she returns me to my work In fact this habit of chatting is hopeless & in the later days I used to spend all the time in other room. 

A salamander is kept going night & day so that I should not have cold & fuel costs something here ie when one can get it. If I lack a book her own work stops still till she finds it & that at a reasonable price of prices of books have just doubled & in some cases they are rare & the prices are fantastique eg costs 5 fr I paid second hand 17 francs

All that this girl has done for me would take too long to tell but I shall return to her tout a l’heure.

This is the usual programme for each day now though I realise the strain cannot endure very long. But if human energy & application can conquer I am determined to win. When I have a definite task which depends on my efforts I can generally bend my will to it there is no end in view like the Bar I have fear.

My health here does gives out finally & suffer from extreme exhaustion on return from Italy. The eyes too give under the strain but Brise doctors me up with colargyrol which is magn. She really ought to have been a doctoresse.
Entry.111:
many of my days follows the above programme that I need not rechronicle it. 

I wish I had some records of all the little thoughtful acts 
that
 of Brise during this period when at the best I could but be regarded as a nuisance in the house. She is all goodness but I have yet to realise the depth of her affection when my life lay in danger in
Entry.112:
She is a jewel without any price. 

Every Sunday I cease work & spend the day in an outing something always taking Brise who represents it herself

119

my pleasantest souvenirs of Paris & so you find diary will principally tell only of Sundays & not very much as I am writing in
Entry.114:
To day we visited Musee Guimet. Brise accompanies on all my visits to Musee as they interest her. 

She is of the type that seeks instruction everywhere & does not expect to find it in dances or cafes. Of little school education for she was educated like Dad She has acquired more knowledge than the ordinary girl especially in the world of art A little savage who shuns puberty & is as 
shy
 timid a dear in company she only shows her knowledge when she meets a kindred spirit.

The musee contains contains a wonderful collection of Chinese pottery which shows how advanced the Chinese are & how ignorant we are. They shame Sevres & that when Europe was almost savage. 

On entering sticks & umbrellas must as usual be given up. No fee is demanded but you cannot get therein without a considerable pourboires which is same thing in my eyes I shall be glad to find a country

where there is no pourboires. A foreigner is always expected. 

One spends more in tips here than one pays for articles. Go into a tea room your cane & hat is taken (tip) waiter serves you (tip) another makes up bill (tip) band plays (tip) woman sings (tip) etc. If tip is not big enough they will tell you. A foreigner pays more than a francais & an officer more than others.

It is because I have no funds that I spend most of time in civvies against orders. It exposes to insults & you cannot retaliate but saves a lot of money & you can go into many a place where uniform would be looked on askance.

However to my musee. Upstairs there is a white mummy (222AD) & a mummy of Thais but query if The Thais of Nicias & the accursed Alexandria. 

The day is a typical Sydney winters day Deluge of rain with a cutting wind which makes you shiver though the temperature is not really low. We shelter while waiting for tram in the open door of some wealthy individual & dive for tram when it arrives.

Here where all buildings are building close to one another there can be no carriage drive to your front door. So the rich have a door wide enough to admit a motor car & you decend inside & are under cover all the time. 

If you were

121

to descend in street you would be wet or your satin shoes would be spoilt in traversing the footpath (In cafes & hotel a flunkey man with a large umbrella protects you from rain). . There is no front door at all & no grand & official exterior entrance. 

On returning we changed our wet clothes & light a huge fire in the open fireplace to dry our things. For here there is no place – no court to dry clothes hence even the poorest is forced to send them to a laundry which even in the poorest families cost 4 to 15 francs per week.

Handkerchiefs cost – 10c

Kitchen Towels – 15c

Never will I be able to adjust my ideas after the prices here. These prices are all a consequences of guerre & the high cost of living. 

In front of huge fire we stretched a eiderdown & read to our hearts content while outside the rain fell & the wind howled. The following day & the rest of week the usual regime of study. I am really worse off than a prisoner in the
Entry.117:
To day being sunday I go on strike as usual. Being late in starting & rather than spoil an excellent dinner we change our plans & start for St German en laye.

In the town itself there is nothing save the chapel which Maurice Denys has erected to memory of his femme & which is private & more not yet finished. The church into which I did not enter contains a bust of James II (erected by Geo IV) who occupied chateau for 12 yrs. 

On other side was another palais of which rests only Pavilion Henri IV. It was at the chateau that peace with Austria was signed. The building is strange not being built square but roughly like plan. The effect is not pleasing. 

The cheauteau is not pretty being built for strength as huge moat indicates but it has none of dignity of old strongholds for one has tried to make it beautiful as well as strong. Brickwork white & red alternated. Statues in bay windows – Effect is heavy. 

Building itself is occupied for most as residence for guardian what is left is a musee of everything in French history of early times down to . Not of much interest except to students. The 

123

Gothic chapel constructed by St Louis is beautiful. But the grand attraction is the Terrace 1 ½ miles long erected by at God knows what cost. But the view of the valley of love is magnificent If weather is clear Montmarte & Eifel Tower are visible. 

Behind terrace is a delightfully laid out garden of the English type & then a hunting area surrounded by a vast wall through which however we find a breach. We continue along the terrace to the end & thence to Chateau du Val where the grounds are admirably laid out. 

I regret that I did not ask permission to enter & make a copy for my future castle. We then entered the Forest 11,000 acres of waste land. The timber is worth nothing but could be easily afforested but here no one cares & all at Paris.

We had a little sandwich of cheese which Brise had carried in her parosol till now & after a little rest & having gathered some ferns & flowers we wandered on. Brise is very fond of flowers & will often buy them for the house. She collected so much that in my eyes were useless that I asked why she wasted her energy carrying useless flowers homes. 

Half an hour after all her flowers had disappeared & I thought she had dropped but no she had thrown them away because she

thought they displeased me & she admitted this like an infant who has done wrong in gathering them or one being found out in doing some good act. Truly her affection & desire to do what I should wish are very touching.

At Maison Lafitte we had an example of the triomph of commercialism over The Chateau de Maison constructed in 1717 in the midst of a beautiful park was acquired in 1818 by Lafitte a banker who lacked sentiment & cut up parts into small building lots which he sold at high prices in order to keep it select & incidentally realise more. The chateau itself is isolated without even a tree to relieve it & fenced in by an iron picket fence it seems a prisoner or a criminal guilty of some crime.

Disgusted we turn homeward & I have just finished selecting a few pc when before I can pay the town supply of electricity fails or is probably cut one is never certain here where respect for law is always lacking. 

At the railway there are two entrances but which is entrance & which exit no one can say. However the entrance is closed & the exit is the entrance & you cross the rails to reach the departure platform. Rather a strange performance & incomprehensible for

125

a foreigner who values his life. But then this is France.
Entry.119:
Study as usual which I will not chronicle for future as it is always the same. My eyes are giving under the strain & it is only Brise & her coleyrol keep them going. 

I begin to get work a little in hand but the task is almost hopeless though while there is a possibility I will carry on perhaps I can fluke it at the worst. While there is life there is hope But to attempt 2 years work in a few months even if the language was the same is somewhat of a large order
Entry.121:
again & a pleasant outing I have arranged for to day. 

Brise has arranged a lovely luncheon basket ctg/fowl, , cheese, fruit, etc – her idea of contributing to expenses. The value she furnishes is out of all proportion to other expenses. 

We start very early & take train at Luxemburg. This is an underground where no attempt to supply fresh air has ever entered into the mind of Directors of the Coy. All lights alight in train

which are extinguished by girl who verifies the tickets & for 5 minutes or so before depart of train of train you rest in darkness except for station lights. 

The line follows Boul Mich in which are escape boxes for steam. Often a surprise to a stranger when he sees one of these boxes idly smoking. Port Royal is an open station & after that tunnel again till clear of city. 

At St Remy les Chevreuse (20 miles from Paris) we descend & as usual French customs we must cross line to leave station. After 5 more miles 
the
 during which train empties passengers who flock to point opposite gate the train moves on but stops immediately & remains there for about ¼ hour. Everyone gets impatient & I suggest to Brise to cross the compartment of train but train moves on. 

Day is glorious & sky clear. 

There is a track leading to Chevreuse & naturally I take to avoid main road. We pass Chateau de Cobertin a deserted & badly placed chateau when so many lovely spots about here. 

On other side some one desirous of view has constructed a chateau on the side of a hill that is almost perpendicular & without any visible means of communication save by climbing hill & by facing his chateau he has lost the best view of the valley. The ruins are visible & easily find the way

127

As ruins they possess no interest though guardian thinks different but the view of the valley especially in the sunshine to day with its squares & patches is well worth the climb. See pc for view.

We descend the chateau by a steep private path used by inmates when during visited here & in a few minutes are in the town. 

We then take the high for Dampierre & the road passes several times a thicket in which the grand trees make a rustic alley though one side is hidden by a high stone wall & one knows that some rich noble has his home behind it. One is hidden by wall but when one comes to the chateau itself the wall ceases & a deep ditch takes its place & a view of grounds & cheateau is possible & it is is nothing exceptional so why the enormous 16 ft wall.

At Dampierre is Chauteau of Lugnes family but we do not enter as family is in residence (but see pc). The road is hot & uninteresting now. Brise finds some apples but they are sour & afterwards some pears. Road has no shelter. 

Senlisse lies to left of hills and so path leads on till we arrive at the Vaux
